After ten revolutions, the spirit within the real is unfathomably numinous; the body’s ten thousand qi all enter the immortal way.

This marks the response of the ten-month internal elixir, when merit is complete and the Dao perfected. Here lies the subtlety of pursuing the two qi along the Yellow Way, uniting the three natures in the primordial palace, drawing emotions back to nature, and returning to the root to restore life—all accomplished through the ten revolutions of practice.

The immortal way values life and delivers boundless beings. Above, the eight gates open, and the celestial Dharma-wheel takes flight. Karmic retribution, prohibitions, past-life causes, and conditions—all receive universal deliverance, where dead souls gain living bodies. Once the body attains rebirth, it ascends to be heard by the various heavens. Above the heavens, each has its own gate of life.

Mo’an says: This speaks of the karmic retribution of worldly beings, yet all may ultimately receive the grace of deliverance. Such is the immortal way of long life. Thus, the Most High cherishes life without limit, universally delivering the infinite. The eight gates are the portals of the eight-directional Dharma-wheel. The good and evil of worldly karma are all created by the mind, giving rise to the division of heaven and hell. People, drowned in the obscuration of greed and lament, unaware of prohibitions, or bound by past-life and present habits, become entangled and stained—hence the retribution of cyclic rebirth. Now, by the great compassion of the Heavenly Worthy, all receive deliverance: above, the eight directional gates open, the Dharma-wheel turns, and the radiance of wisdom shines swiftly like flying celestials, penetrating the darkest depths. Thus, dead souls are delivered and gain living bodies. Having received rebirth, one must rely on the talismanic decree of the Primordial Beginning to petition the heavens, whereupon the heavens, according to one’s merit and endowment, grant a living body—resulting in ranks of immortals, high and low. Dead souls, following the gate of karmic rebirth, each receive the grace of deliverance.

The gate of life refers to the "gate of life and door of death" spoken of in the *Scripture of Life Spirits*. Above the heavens, each has its own jurisdiction. Within them lies the empty cavern, the verses of chanting songs, the numinous chapters of demon kings, and the words that match the exalted perfected. Mo’an says: This is the preface to the demon kings’ songs, where the Primordial Beginning selects their verses to harmonize with the cavernous chapters of the exalted perfected. The "empty cavern" refers to the "empty cavern within heaven" mentioned earlier. The "chanting songs" are the demon kings’ verses. This preface to the demon kings’ songs of the three realms cites the Primordial Beginning’s words to match the cavernous chapters, hence incorporating them among the exalted perfected—this is called the *Numinous Chapter*.

The scriptures and methods state: The cavernous chapters are the cinnabar and yellow of Mount Gui, the soaring mysterious purple script—not composed by demon kings. The Most High disseminated these three chapters to the world, enabling people to awaken and transcend the three realms. When the Heavenly Worthy descended to subdue the demons, the demon kings all bowed their heads in submission, and were commanded to govern the three realms, each singing verses that transform and fly through the void, warning celestial and human beings, repelling desire-demons, so that those who hear this flying celestial sound turn from the suffering of sensual desire and return to the gate of purity.

The preceding text states: "Above the heavens, each has its own gate of life," and continues, "within them lies the empty cavern and verses of chanting songs"—thus, within the heavens, there are naturally cavernous chapters. The demon kings’ flying celestial songs, in their meaning of reverence and warning, resonate with the celestial perfected, and are thus worthy to be matched with the exalted perfected.

The first is the flying celestial sound of the Desire Realm:

Mo’an says: The Desire Realm lies at the boundary between celestials and humans; in the human body, it is the realm of heart and kidneys. Transcending the ghost path leads to humanity; entering the immortal way leads to flying through the void. Gu Yu says: The demon king’s name is Yu Mo. The Daoist scriptures state: If one’s oral karma is pure, possessing ten good deeds or more, one is born in the six heavens of the Desire Realm. The *Lingbao Scriptures and Methods* state: From Huangzeng to Moye is the Desire Realm; when the six desires are all purified, one ascends to the Form Realm.

The human path is faint and distant, the immortal way vast and remote;
The ghost path delights in endings, while the human gate is life.
The celestial way values life, the ghost way values death.
The immortal way is ever auspicious, the ghost way ever inauspicious.
Exalted, pure, and numinous, I chant sorrowfully in the great void.
I only wish the immortal way to succeed, not the human path to perish.
The Northern Capital’s Spring Bend Prefecture holds a myriad ghostly hosts,
All seeking to cut short human lifespans and sever the gate of life.
Ah! Sing the cavernous chapters to restrain the Northern Feng,
Bind and dispatch the demonic essences, behead the six ghostly blades.
The qi of the various heavens surges boundlessly, my Dao daily flourishes.

Mo’an says: This speaks of the Northern Capital’s Spring Bend Prefecture within our bodies—namely, the Northern Feng. The myriad ghostly hosts are the demonic essences and six ghostly blades. If I can restrain, bind, dispatch, and behead them, then the celestial qi daily grows within me, and the immortal way daily manifests within me.

"Faint and distant" means subtle and elusive. "Vast and remote" means lofty and far-reaching. The "gate of life" is the threshold of life and death. "Numinous spirits" refers to the ghostly realm. The Spring Bend Prefecture is the northern yin within the body. The "gate of life" is the stem of life. The human path is faint and fleeting, subtle and hard to exhaust; the immortal way is lofty, remote, and hard to fathom. Thus, from the moment humans take form, they become attached and bound—eyes to forms, ears to sounds, nose to scents, mouth to tastes—all roots of the three poisons and six desires, leading to the retribution of the three paths and five sufferings. Because people cannot cultivate the immortal way, the ghost path seems joyful, standing at the gate of human life and death, seeking only human annihilation. Thus, the celestial way cherishes life, while ghosts value death.

Yet those who pursue the immortal way must cultivate virtue and accumulate goodness, and whatever they summon will be auspicious. Those who sink into the ghost path must harm virtue and goodness, and whatever they seek will be inauspicious. "Exalted, pure, and numinous"—the demon king speaks of his dwelling’s vastness, which no numinous spirit can invade. Chanting sorrowfully, flying through the great void, he pities those who drift far from the immortal way.

May scholars only aspire to the fulfillment of the immortal Dao, not the exhaustion of the human way. The Northern Metropolis’ Springs and Bends Prefecture is none other than the Northern Metropolis of Fengdu. The Dark Pass is governed by Mount Tai, where the office oversees the meting of punishments, the tallying of transgressions, and the recording of faults. The Three Realms’ Four Bureaus—mountains, rivers, moats, and altars—on the Three Origins, Eight Festivals, Five La Days, and Three Assemblies, examine and assess merits and demerits with impartiality, down to the finest detail. Those who uphold goodness and cultivate blessings extend their years and lengthen their lives; those who do evil and incur misfortune have their allotted years erased and their lifespans cut short, their records sent to Fengdu’s Springs and Bends. Within Fengdu’s precincts, a multitude of ghosts conspire to intercept and sever human lifespans, cutting off the root of life, unwilling to see the immortal Dao fulfilled.

The Northern Metropolis of Fengdu within the human body is the River of Love and Sea of Desire. If one cannot restrain desire and nurture the heart-mind, then deluded thoughts scatter like flying dust, all becoming demonic spirits. Ah, let one chant the empty and cavernous verses to subdue and restrain Fengdu’s ghosts, driving them to be bound, sent away, and beheaded, so that the blades of the six demonic ghosts may instantly vanish and fall silent. With inner cultivation and outer conduct accumulated, and myriad virtues perfected day by day, the celestial way’s true radiance will flourish boundlessly, and our Dao shall thus prosper.

**Second: The Chapter of the Form Realm’s Demon King**

Mo’an says: The Form Realm is the heaven of the middle heavens; within humans, it is the realm of the heart-mind and eyes. Free from attachment, one can transform, take flight, and ascend. Shaowei says: The Demon King’s name is Mara. The Daoist scriptures state: With three hundred virtuous deeds in bodily conduct, one is born into the Form Realm. From Yuexing Heaven to Tanshi Heaven, there are eighteen heavens in all, comprising the Form Realm. The people of this heaven possess form but no desire; their allotments are subtle and light, the eighteen dusts, and the dusts’ defilements are all purified, ascending to the Formless Realm.

Lofty and vast, luminous qi spreads in all four directions. The Brahma-conduct heavens encircle the ten directions. Boundless great spirits all arise from within my body. I possess cavernous verses—ten thousand recitations, and one becomes immortal. The immortal Dao values deliverance; the ghost path clings fast. Heaven and earth stretch boundless, foul qi swirling thickly. Within the Three Realms, joy endures—pass beyond it, and it abides long. Crossing my realm, the body enters spontaneity. At this time, joy is but a trifling grace of mine. The Dragon Han is vast—how can one distinguish the true? My realm is hard to cross, so I compose these cavernous texts. Transforming and flying through the void, I test your body. Success or failure, slackening or retreat—how many will cross? I laugh at those who do not cross, so I sing these songs.

“Lofty” describes the vastness of the celestial body. “Luminous qi” refers to the bright and pure Brahma-qi, spreading in all four directions, flowing through the heavens of the ten directions, pervading all. The “boundless great spirits” are the Demon King’s words on his limitless transformations, all the spirits within his body. The “cavernous verses” are the aforementioned cinnabar-yellow texts of Mount Gui, the soaring mysterious purple script, fully recorded in the *Lingbao* methods—this is not the Demon King’s song. “Ten thousand recitations” means that only after long and sincere accumulation of power will effort reach fruition and immortality be achieved—not merely through frequent recitation.

What the immortal Dao values is long life and deliverance from the world. What the ghost path entangles is this: when people cannot cultivate themselves, their bodies perish and their qi disperses; their hun and shen are examined, and their ancestors and forebears are implicated. Heaven and earth are vast and boundless, yet foul and turbid qi swirls and intertwines within them. Within the Three Realms, only those who transcend can abide long and attain supreme joy. “My realm” is the Demon King’s self-reference. Those who cross this realm merge their bodies with spontaneity, all habitual tendencies forgotten, ascending into the formless. At this stage, the six senses are all purified, the eight consciousnesses all empty, utterly serene and unified in truth—its joy is boundless. Though this arises from the fulfillment of power and virtue, it is also through the Demon King’s sponsorship that one becomes immortal. Thus it is said: “a trifling grace of mine.”

The Dragon Han is the name of the Primordial Beginning’s first kalpa, vast and boundless. At the dawn of the ancestral kalpa, the great simplicity had not yet dispersed, and the true nature of original being was undifferentiated—how could there be distinctions of purity and impurity, refinement and coarseness? Once human desire arose and emotions and perceptions obscured it, the original nature became divided, and karmic consciousness flowed endlessly, until even my realm became hard to cross. Thus I compose these cavernous texts to instruct and encourage, desiring that people realize the Dao and attain truth, crossing this realm.

The “cavernous texts” are the song-verses. “Transforming and flying through the void,” the Demon King speaks of his unfathomable spiritual transformations, testing the hearts of Dao cultivators: sometimes with what they desire, sometimes with what they fear, sometimes with what they neither desire nor fear. Over days and months, if the heart becomes like iron and stone, unwavering and without slackening, then the Dao’s work is accomplished. Yet how many, despite success or failure, slackening or retreat, are not deterred by demons and ultimately cross the Three Realms? Some falter midway, incurring the Demon King’s laughter—they do not cross. The songs are composed with good intent to encourage. Those who cultivate must accumulate merit and conduct over time, connecting with the numinous. Then inner demons do not arise, outer demons naturally cease, the Dao’s work is accomplished, and one can be delivered from the world.

**Third: The Song of the Formless Realm’s Demon King**

Mo’an says: The Formless Realm in heaven is the celestial summit; within humans, it is the Niwan summit. Shaowei says: The Demon King’s name is Shao. The Daoist scriptures state: With six hundred virtuous deeds in the heart-mind, one is born into the Formless Realm’s four heavens. From Haoting Heaven to Xiule’s four heavens, these comprise the Formless Realm. The *Benji Jing* says: Afflictions are knots; learning and conduct are habits. When knots and habits are exhausted, one transcends the rank of the seed people.

Entering the cavernous Dao’s境, one ascends and descends with the qi, untouched by calamity. Above the Three Realms, the vast and distant Great Luo.

Above the rootless Formless, cloud-layers rise in towering peaks.
Only the Primordial Beginning dwells in the home of vast kalpas.
It governs and orders our realm, receiving its mandate from Mysterious Capital.
Whoever transgresses our realm enters the Jade Void.
My station is the supreme king, rectifying and ruling all demons.
In the emptiness, ten thousand transformations arise; impure qi blooms in profusion.
Those who preserve the true are few; those who stray and delude are many.
The immortal Dao is hard to secure; the ghostly path easily turns to deviance.
The human path lies in the heart-mind—truly, it does not depend on others.
The immortal Dao values substance; the human path values splendor.
If you do not delight in the immortal Dao, how can you pass beyond the Three Realms?
Should you wish to revolve through the Five Paths, what then can I do for you?

Mo’an says: The vast and distant Great Luo refers to the summit of the thirty-two heavens. Heaven is governed by the Northern Culmen, which orders all heavens. The rootless Formless refers to the summit of the three hundred sixty bones and joints. In humans, the Hundred Meetings governs the entire body. Guanfu says: Above the Three Realms lies the Four Heavens of the Seed People, which is the Great Luo Heaven. Above the Great Luo Heaven stands the Jade Capital Mountain, veiled by layered clouds. Since the beginning of vast kalpas, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy has dwelt within, governing the Three Realms and ruling the Mysterious Capital’s Great Luo Jade Clarity. Our realm is the Formless Realm. The Jade Void is the Void’s Jade Capital. Those who cultivate and refine, attaining deliverance from the Formless Realm and entering the Four Heavens of the Seed People, then enter the realm of the Jade Void. My station is the supreme king—the Demon King declares his merit and rank stand above all other demon kings, thus all demons are rectified and ruled by him. Gazing down upon the emptiness, the dusts of form and the filth of karma arise and vanish in ten thousand transformations; impure and turbid qi intertwine in profusion. Thus, those who can preserve and secure their original true nature are few, while those who become deluded and confused are many. The immortal Dao cannot be firmly established, and one easily falls into the deviance of the ghostly path. The human path: when the heart-mind gathers it, the ten thousand differences return to one root; when it scatters, one root becomes ten thousand differences. Each thing possesses its own Supreme Ultimate—none but this heart-mind. The human heart, the Dao-heart, preserving the heart, nurturing the heart, rectifying the heart, cultivating the heart, observing the heart, settling the heart, illuminating the heart—all Three Teachings share this single heart-method. How could there be another? The immortal Dao values substance: sincerity without falsehood. The human path delights in competitive splendor. If one does not delight in the immortal Dao and aspire to self-cultivation, how can one pass beyond the Three Realms? Thus, one must revolve through the suffering wheel of the Five Paths—what then can I do? This is the Demon King’s earnest admonition. The Five Paths are: gods, humans, birds and beasts, hungry ghosts, and hells.

This realm above the Three Realms, in the flying emptiness, is where the Demon King’s song resounds, its tones interwoven with cavernous chapters. Reciting it a hundred times delivers one to the Southern Palace. Reciting it a thousand times, the Demon King protects and welcomes. After ten thousand recitations, the Dao is complete—one soars into the great emptiness, passes beyond the Three Realms, and ascends to the rank of Immortal Duke. This is the general praise for the preceding song.

The Demon King, in the realm above the Three Realms, flies through the great emptiness, composing his song. It can be interwoven with the subtle wonders of cavernous chapters, guiding cultivators to daily progress on the Way. From the Realm of Desire through the Realm of Form to the Formless Realm, reciting and chanting its tones—first a hundred, then a thousand, then ten thousand times—there is no fear of slackening or retreat, only the aspiration that each thought returns to the true. Thus, the difficulty of attaining the embodied Dao can only be overcome by those with resolute will and steadfast conduct. Only after ten thousand recitations, when the Dao is complete, can one soar into the great emptiness, pass beyond the Three Realms, and attain the rank of Immortal Duke. The Immortal Duke is the highest rank of the Supreme Ultimate’s immortal grades. Moreover, ten thousand recitations are not merely oral recitation—they require the power of deep accumulation and thick cultivation through inner work and outer conduct, only then can one ascend into the great emptiness and attain the immortal ranks. Thus, the Heavenly Worthy included it in the orthodox scriptures, praising it: "This numinous chapter and numinous tone—its power of summoning is truly of the utmost weight." Therefore, its words interweave with those of the lofty perfected, its tones with cavernous chapters.

Those who hear the numinous tone, the Demon King respects their form. He commands earth spirits to attend and protect, escorting them in departure and return. They are plucked from the earthly gate, freed from the five sufferings and eight hardships. Seven generations of ancestors ascend and migrate, forever departing the ghostly officials. The soul crosses the Vermilion Mound, undergoes refinement, and is reborn. This is called boundless deliverance, universally liberating without end. There are secret celestial texts, revered by all heavens. Those who leak and slight them fall into hell, bringing calamity upon seven generations of ancestors.

Mo’an says: This speaks of the universal deliverance of the demonic chapters and the retribution for scholars who leak and slight. The Primordial Beginning’s scriptural teachings end here. The "numinous tone" praises the weight of the Demon King’s song. Those who hear this tone and cultivate without negligence—the Demon King reveres their form and spirit. Thus, Guanfu says: Hearing is not merely ear-hearing; it requires the heart to commune with the scripture and conduct to align with the scripture. Thoughts must never be forgotten, always maintaining reverence and awe. Externally, one dispels all conditions; internally, one cultivates the power of concentration. Over time, with deep merit and complete conduct, the Celestial Thearch commands the spirits of earthly sacrifices to attend and protect one’s dwelling, escorting departures and returns. Even if the Dao is not yet complete and one cannot pass beyond the Three Realms or attain the rank of Immortal Duke, one is still plucked from the earthly gate, freed from the gate of death. No longer subject to the hardships of the five sufferings and eight difficulties, one’s merit extends upward to seven generations of ancestors, all ascending and migrating, forever departing the dark passes and no longer subject to the governance of ghostly officials. The soul directly crosses the Vermilion Mound’s Fire Bureau and is reborn in the realm of bliss. Thus, both life and death receive its boundless merit and endless deliverance. At this stage of inner work, the sacred embryo is complete—one sheds the body, spirit transforms, yin is exhausted, and yang is pure. One directly transcends above the Three Realms, and seven generations of ancestors ascend together.

Although the effects of scriptural merit are thus manifest, if this secret is revered by all heavens above, those who commit the transgression of leaking and slighting will not only fall into hell themselves but will also bring calamity upon seven generations of ancestors. One cannot but be warned and cautious.

The Dao speaks: These two chapters are the hidden tones of the Celestial Theads and the Most Numinous Demon Kings—all utterances of the Great Brahma, not common words of the mundane world. Their speech lacks ornate rhythm, their melodies lack florid grace; thus are they called profound and obscure, difficult to fathom in detail. Treasured by the heavens, they are kept secret in the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace of the Dark Capital. According to the Mystic Statutes, they are transmitted but once in forty thousand kalpas. Should a perfected one bring gold and treasures with a sincere heart, following the ancient protocols to pledge oaths before the Ten Heavens, only then may they be conferred.

Master Silent Hermitage says: From this point to the five sections of the "Utmost Clarity’s Perfect Words," these are the Dao Lord’s further exposition on the wondrous functions of the scripture—indeed, the postface to the main text. These two chapters of the *Lingbao* postface refer specifically to the preceding first chapter, "The Primordial Beginning’s Cavernous Mystery *Lingbao* Original Chapter," and the following second chapter, "The Chapter of Empty Cavern’s Songs and Chants." Treasured by the heavens, this is the Dao Lord’s further exposition on the scripture’s profound wonders, reflecting the celestial reverence for them.

Master Observing Return says: These two chapters are the *Hundun Crimson Writ* and the *Primordial Cavern Jade Chronicle*. One elucidates the Dao of the Prior Heaven, the other the Dao of the Posterior Heaven. The *Hundun Crimson Writ* records the names and taboo titles of the Celestial Thearchs and the five celestial designations, its text centered on transcending the arts of the Mystic Ancestors, receiving deliverance in the body of life, unfolding universal salvation, and the purport of traversing passes to proclaim destiny. The *Primordial Cavern Jade Chronicle* speaks of the success and failure of kalpic cycles, the opening of the primordial chaos, the circulation of the primordial qi, the extraction and refinement of cultivation, the return to the root and restoration of destiny, and the Dao of transcending the ordinary to enter sagehood. Thus are they called hidden tones and utterances of the Great Brahma, beyond the reach of common speech. "Speech lacks ornate rhythm" refers to the purity and subtlety of the Heavenly Worthy’s scriptural essence; "melodies lack florid grace" refers to the clarity and simplicity of the Demon Kings’ songs. Yet their meaning is profound and recondite, scholars unable to exhaust its intricacies. As for the words of Patriarch Silent Hermitage, from the *Lingbao* Original Chapter to the Chapter of Songs and Chants, these are the two chapters—though their text and meaning are one, the *Crimson Writ* and *Jade Chronicle* are contained therein. All are hidden utterances of the Great Brahma, thus treasured by the heavens in the Dark Capital’s Purple Tenuity Palace, transmitted only after countless kalpas in accordance with the Mystic Statutes and prohibitions. How dare one lightly divulge or recklessly transmit them? Those aspirants who seek to receive the scripture must bring gold with a sincere heart, following the celestial perfected ones’ protocols to pledge oaths before the Heavenly Worthy’s sagely host before transmission may be granted. How could one treat them with carelessness, regarding them as common speech? These are all the Dao Lord’s most earnest and solemn instructions.

The Dao speaks: The revolutions of heaven and earth, too, have their ends of adversity; the sun, moon, and five planets, too, have their waxings and wanings; even the utmost sagely and divine beings have their flourishings and declines; and the lesser learners, too, have their illnesses and afflictions.

Whenever such calamities arise, those of shared qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times through. Thereupon, virtue and power descend at once, dissolving all inauspiciousness. These boundless texts universally deliver limitless beings.

Heaven and earth are the root of the myriad things, yet ultimately confined by form and qi; their revolutions, too, have their adversities and prosperities. Thus, when encountering the tribulations of the Nine Yangs and Hundred Sixes, the Three Realms perish, only to be reconstituted thereafter. The celestial courses of the sun, moon, and five planets, too, have their eclipses and fluctuations; even the utmost sagely and divine beings have their passages and blockages, flourishings and declines—how much more the lesser learners, could they be free of illness and affliction? Therefore, when suffering the bitterness of illness and adversity, one must willingly accept and not complain, thereby aligning with Heaven.

Yet humans, heaven and earth, and the myriad things are all of a single qi—this is called "one root, ten thousand differences." The former scholars spoke of Qian as father and Kun as mother, of the people as our siblings and things as our single body—this is what they meant. Thus, whenever such calamities arise, those of shared qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times through. Whether to dissolve celestial disasters above or deliver the multitudes below, to ward off adversity and sustain the declining, there is no prayer that goes unanswered. Thus, virtue and power descend at once, dissolving all inauspiciousness—all through the efficacy of the tenfold recitation. Truly, these are boundless texts that universally deliver heaven and humanity without end.

The Dao speaks: The lesser learners, their Dao shallow and immortal rank unfulfilled, when their destined time of extinction arrives, their bodies pass through the Great Yin. At the hour of their passing, fellow learners and perfected ones perform incense offerings and recite the scripture ten times to deliver their corporeal forms. By this method, the hun-souls ascend directly to the Southern Palace, where, according to their accumulated merit, they are reborn after a reckoning of days. Their wheel of rebirth unbroken, they thereby attain divine transcendence.

This is spoken especially for the lesser learners of shallow Dao, whose immortal rank remains unfulfilled. When their destined time of extinction arrives, their cultivation of the immortal Dao incomplete and their bodies not yet purely yang, they must pass through the trials of the Great Yin. The Great Yin is akin to the Northern Yin Springs’ winding depths. At the hour of their passing—when their allotted time nears its end—fellow learners and perfected ones, those of the same teacher or Dao who have attained realization, must perform incense offerings and recite the scripture ten times through to deliver their corporeal forms. By this method, they borrow the perfected ones’ refined yang to recite the scripture, thereby delivering the extreme yin of the corpse and sending the hun-souls to ascend and be reborn in the Southern Palace. The *shi* (corpse) is the untransformed *po*; the *xing* (form) is the untransformed qi. Only through the merit of the scripture and the power of the Dao, refining the substance and molding the hun, can they ascend directly to the Southern Palace. According to their accumulated merit, they are reborn after a reckoning of days, each receiving rebirth in accordance with their learning’s depth and their virtue’s height. Their wheel of rebirth unable to extinguish their fundamental nature, their single spirit undimmed, over time, through the accumulation of profound practice, they, too, attain the immortal Dao.

The Dao speaks: When the revolutions of heaven and earth reach their end, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When the stellar lodges deviate from their courses and the sun and moon lose their proper times, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When the sovereign faces calamity and warfare arises on all sides, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When pestilential toxins spread and the multitudes perish, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When teachers and friends pass away, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture.

Purification rites and scripture recitation carry immense merit. Above, they dissolve celestial disasters and secure the emperor’s reign; below, they dispel toxins and deliver the multitudes. In life and death, all rely upon them—such blessings are beyond measure. Thus, they are called boundless, universally delivering heaven and humanity.

Qingyuan said: In this chapter, the Dao Lord clarifies that this scripture not only delivers oneself but also universally aids heaven and earth, sovereigns and ministers, the people and all things—only then is the Dao complete, manifesting the universal deliverance of beings. When the revolutions of heaven and earth reach their end, according to the Supreme Ultimate’s Yuan-Hui-Yun-Shi reckoning, even heaven and earth have their formations and dissolutions, cycles they cannot escape. As the *Book of Changes* says, "When heaven and earth perish, there is nothing by which to observe their transformations." The human body and the workings of creation share the same path, thus one may align with heaven and earth, assist in transformation and nurturance, regulate the Dao, and harmonize its principles. The former scholars did not speak of the unity of heaven and humanity’s governance as merely the oneness of heart and principle. That which governs is called the Emperor; its wondrous functioning is called ghosts and spirits—are they not one and the same? Thus, when the revolutions face adversity and decline, one must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel them.

When the stellar lodges deviate from their courses, their celestial positions errant and their shadow-measures awry; when the sun and moon lose their proper times, their waxings and wanings eclipsed—these, too, are confined by the numbers of delay, concealment, and retrogression. One must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel them. When the four seasons lose their order, cold and heat irregular; when yin and yang fall out of harmony, droughts and floods wreak havoc—these, too, arise from deviations in heaven and earth’s supreme harmony. One must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel them. When the sovereign faces calamity and warfare arises on all sides, all such disasters and conflicts stem from yin and yang’s rebellion and governance’s discord. Cultivating virtuous rule, reducing punishments, comforting the people, managing the military, appointing the worthy, and stabilizing the altars of soil and grain—these are the means to dissolve celestial portents and quell human suffering. This is the foremost duty of sagely rulers and worthy ministers. Yet if such calamities arise, one must also perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel and restrain them, thereby petitioning Heaven, which will surely quell disasters and send down auspiciousness.

When pestilential toxins spread and the multitudes perish, the *qi* of epidemic pestilence poisons the people, inevitably causing death and injury. One must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel and release them, rectifying the *qi*’s conditions so that the pestilential *qi* subsides.

When masters and friends pass beyond, for masters transmit the Dao and impart learning, while friends assist in cultivating benevolence and enhancing virtue—these are among the cardinal principles of human relations. At the time of their passing, one must also perform purification rites and recite the scripture to deliver and ferry them across. Having spoken of masters and friends, one may infer the same for parents and kin.

Now, purification rites and scripture recitation carry profound merit and virtue; herein the Dao Lord extols the merits of this scripture. Internally, they empty the heart to refine *qi*, align with the spirits, and preserve authenticity; externally, their merit can ascend to dissolve celestial disasters, safeguard and stabilize the emperor, descend to dispel toxins and harm, and deliver the multitudes. This may be said to extend its blessings to ruler and minister, people and all beings without exception—its merit is boundless, universally ferrying heaven and humanity alike.

The Dao states: Whoever possesses this scripture and performs these meritorious deeds for Heaven and Earth, the divine sovereigns, and the multitudes—on days of disaster, if one arouses the mind to perform purification rites, burns incense, and recites the scripture ten times—all the heavens will record their name, myriad spirits will attend and guard them, and those of superior attainment will swiftly become ministers of the Golden Portals of the sagely ruler. The heavens record one’s merits and transgressions with unfailing precision, down to the finest detail. The demon kings of heaven will also protect and recommend them, and those who attain the Dao will thereby fully comprehend the most profound teachings.

Mo’an says: Here the Dao Lord once more expounds the efficacy of scholars’ recitation and practice. This passage further summarizes the preceding sections—all are the earnest instructions left by the Dao Lord. Whenever disaster arises, if one burns incense and recites the scripture to perform these meritorious deeds for Heaven and Earth, sun and moon, divine sovereigns, and the multitudes, then the heavens will inscribe their name in the registers of immortals, myriad spirits will attend and guard them on all sides—all achieved through the accumulation of scriptural merit. Those of superior attainment, whose learning has reached its apex, may in an instant ascend to the ranks of immortals, serve the Three Realms as ministers, and spiritually wander the Golden Portals.

The heavens record one’s merits and transgressions with unfailing precision, down to the finest detail, while the demon kings of heaven also protect and recommend them—this repetition serves as the utmost admonition, urging practitioners to diligence in their efforts. Each heaven has its own bureaus of inspection and record-keeping; merits and transgressions, no matter how minute, are recorded without the slightest omission. Merits lead to ascension in the ranks of immortals, while transgressions are consigned to the ledgers of sin—there is no partiality or error. Those who cultivate in accordance with the scripture’s merit will have the demon kings of heaven protect and recommend them, inscribing their names in the heavens.

Those who attain the Dao do so through the scripture, thereby fully comprehending the most authentic and profound teachings, plumbing the depths of the most mysterious Dao. Inwardly seeking it, this is the way of the spirit dwelling in the Mud Pill Palace, the path of nurturing and refinement.

*The Comprehensive Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Beginning’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity, Scroll the Third* (concluded)

*The Comprehensive Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Beginning’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity, Scroll the Fourth*

**Annotations by Zhang Yu Chu, the Forty-Third Celestial Master of the Orthodox Unity Lineage, Inheritor of the Dao, Expounder of Non-Action, Illustrious Ancestor, and Perfected Radiant Model, Overseer of Daoist Affairs**

**The Immeasurable Sounds of the Great Brahma Hidden Language in the Heavens**   *Composed by the Dao Lord*

Mò’ān observes: This is the preface to the central chapter of the *Numinous Writ*, transmitted from the Jade Dawn Dao Lord’s composition.

“The Heavens” refers to the midst of the Four Outer Heavens. According to the *Inner Pointer Scripture*: The Primordial Celestial Worthy, seated in the Cypress Mound Pavilion of the Crimson Clarity World, was enveloped in swirling mists for seven days and nights, the dark yin unyielding. The Five Elders addressed the Celestial Worthy, saying: “Today, as we attend your seat, we witness what has never been seen before.” When the Celestial Worthy expounded the teachings, rivers and seas fell silent, mountains and peaks concealed their clouds. Yet now, in broad daylight, the sky darkens, and heavenly beings tremble in fear—what is the cause? The Celestial Worthy replied: “Today, the Heavens emit auspicious signs, numinous responses arising naturally. Jade characters blaze with radiance, veiling the light of heaven. Let all present close their eyes.” In an instant, the celestial qi surged forth, the gloom dissolved, and five-colored light illumined the ten directions. Suddenly, a *Numinous Writ* appeared in the void above, each character a *zhang* in size, its resplendent script and eight-cornered rays dazzling the eye, impossible to behold directly. The Celestial Worthy proclaimed to all: “This *Numinous Writ* of the Eight Assemblies bears characters without fixed form, its purport profound and abstruse, difficult to fathom. Let it be annotated.” Thereupon, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign received the Celestial Worthy’s mandate to explicate its meaning and transmit it to the Dao Lord, that those in the Heavens destined for perfection—those with immortal names—might be instructed.

Guānfù observes: The *Great Brahma* refers to the qi of the Primordial Great Brahma, whose convergence and divergence produce the sounds of Brahma. *Hidden language* denotes the secrets concealed within the Heavens, incomprehensible to mortals. *Immeasurable sounds* signify that beings of all realms and kinds may hear its wondrous meaning without limit. Comprising two hundred and sixty-five characters, they are distributed across the Thirty-Two Heavens, eight characters to each. Inscribed upon the palaces and towers of the Mysterious Capital’s celestial bureaus, they align with each practitioner’s cultivation, allowing their qi to return to its proper abode. Thus, the sounds of the Great Brahma pervade the immeasurable yet remain hidden within the Heavens, untransmittable without the brush of the Perfected Sovereign. Some append the upper and lower chapters of the *Numinous Writ*, along with the Dragon Seal’s orthodox text—materials rejected by Lei Xiao—hence their omission here.

**The Central Chapter of the Primordial Numinous Writ**
Mò’ān observes: The *Numinous Writ* is the *Jade-Character Scripture of the Immeasurable Sounds of the Great Brahma Hidden Language*. The *central chapter* is the chapter of the Center. *Primordial* denotes that it was spoken by the Primordial Celestial Worthy, annotated by the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign, and transmitted to the Dao Lord. The *central chapter of the Numinous Writ* is thus the central chapter of the *Great Brahma Hidden Language*.

Guānfù observes: The Former Perfected declared that this *Numinous Writ* corresponds to the sixty-four hexagrams of the *Great Change*. This scripture predates Heaven and Earth, existing before the hexagrams. The Queen Mother of the West said: “Nine suns guide Qian and Kun; the Mother covers the two hexagrams in the East.” Thus, Qian and Kun originate here, followed by *Tun* and *Meng*, culminating in *Jiji* and *Weiji*, forming the warp and woof of creation. Below, the sixty *jiazi* cycles are arrayed, clarifying the qi’s numerical beginning and end. Next, the twelve hexagrams of the monthly nodes and seasonal markers illustrate the yearly alternation of yin and yang, the progression of cold and heat. Further distinctions of waxing and waning moons elucidate a single month. Twelve double-hours are then marked to regulate the daily advance and retreat of the fire-phase and water-tally. For the yearly seasonal markers are compressed into a month, two and a half days equating to one month, and the twelve hexagrams corresponding to the twelve double-hours, collapsing a month into a single day. Each double-hour equates to two and a half days, hence the upper and lower hexagrams differ in application. The *jiazi* cycles and seasonal markers thus serve distinct purposes. In sum, the upper hexagrams pertain to the *jiazi* scripture, while the lower hexagrams govern seasonal markers and temporal reckoning. By inwardly observing the mind’s movement and stillness, ebb and flow, one naturally grasps the intent and words, and the subtlest principles are fully contained herein. Thus, the meaning of this chapter aligns effortlessly with the wonders of the *Great Change*. The Primordial One expounded this scripture before Fu Xi drew the hexagrams—how could it rely on the *Change* to elucidate the Great Brahma’s text? The principle is one and the same; hence, they coincide like tallying tokens, requiring no forced alignment. By this reasoning, from the Queen Mother of the West onward, masters such as Mò’ān and Shǎowēi have all expounded on the *Change*’s imagery. Yet in Guānfù’s view, their interpretations remain superficial. Here, a comprehensive diagram is appended, harmonizing with Shào’s *Prior Heaven*, Wèi’s *Triplex Unity*, and Péng’s *Heart Mirror*. In its mechanism of advancing yang fire and retreating yin tally, it approaches perfection.

**The Eight Heavens of the East**
*Dǎnlóu āxī, wúhé guān yīn guàn yīn.*
Eight characters, the inner sounds of the Yellow-Canopy Heaven.
*Dǎn*: Vast and boundless in appearance.
*Lóu*: The name of the long tower beneath the Jade Capital Mountain, supporting the Mysterious Capital’s bureaus.
*Ā*: The Ānà spirit of the Mysterious Capital, overseer of the tower, steward of the Great Brahma’s qi. When the qi’s cycles complete, Ānà strikes the tower’s drum to assemble the Perfected, who ascend to pay homage to the Primordial One.
*Cāng*: The name of the Imperial Lord’s terrace, verdant and luxuriant.
*Wú*: The Great Vacuity. Within the Great Nothingness, true sages naturally arise.
*Hé*: The name of the gate of sun and moon. In the Heavens, sun and moon converge at this gate.
*Guān*: Perception. This is the Heavenly Emperor’s taboo name.
*Yīn*: The sound of the eight characters. Those who recite them will have Perfected Ones ride golden wheels to dispel darkness, Jade Maidens unfurl flowered banners and brandish swords, the Perceiver of Awakening preside over the ledgers of eternal night, the Four Perfected relieve the suffering of the Nine Dark Realms, the seven ancestors emerge into brightness, and withered bones revive.

At *Xūyán*, the Bright-Headed One grasps the *Pútán*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Jade Perfection Heaven.

*Xūyán*: The name of the northwest gate of the Jade Perfection Heaven. When the great kalpas intersect, *Xūyán* opens here, and the Jade Perfected and Upper Sages return here.
*Míngshǒu*: The Capital Marquis of the Primordial Beginning. When the Primordial Beginning inaugurates the kalpa, the Capital Marquis initiates the Dao, and the qi of Brahman conduct instantly brightens.
*Fǎ*: The field of the Dharma Wheel’s karmic retribution.
*Lǎn*: Awakening. This is the Heavenly Emperor Lord’s taboo name, presiding over the deliverance of souls and their rebirth.
*Pú*: *Bodhi*. Holding the nine-colored staff.
*Tán*: *Tányí*. Grasping the ten-absolute banner.

Together, these are the Upper Primordial Perfected, who, by constantly reciting the Cavern Chapters, cause the Dharma Wheel to guide the ledgers, Awakening to deliver souls, *Bodhi* to turn the wheel, and *Tányí* to unfurl the banner. Heaven and Earth thereby avoid collapse, and the myriad beings attain eternal existence.

The Azure Primordial says: *Fǎlǎn Pútán* are the Perfected of the Four Courts of the Jade Purity.

*Jiànà Āyì*, *Hūhē Liúyín*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Hoary Youth Heaven.

*Jiànà*: The title of the Heavenly Master of Charts, overseeing the ledgers of human life and death, governing immortals, and presiding over the Golden Flower Palace.
*Āyì*: The name of a tree in the Seven Treasures Grove, covering the four directions. Its fruits are the playground of the Upper Sages and the garden of the Perfected.
*Hū*: Awakening. The name of a flying heavenly spirit, presiding over the convergence of great and small kalpas.
*Hē*: *Hēmó*. In Heaven, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy is called *Hēmó*.
*Liúyín*: The dissemination of chanted hymns. When the kalpa’s destiny ends, *Hēmó* reveals the teachings to universally deliver heavenly and human beings. As the kalpa nears destruction, the true scriptures are concealed, and the Heavenly Worthy, foreknowing this, preemptively sings the hymns.

Those who constantly recite the Cavern Chapters will have the Master of Charts erase their sin records in the eternal night and inscribe their names in the Southern Palace.

*Huādū Qūlì*, *Xiānpú Yùzhēn*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Level Nurturance Heaven.

*Huādū*: An alternate name for the Azure Flower Gate of the Great Ultimate Palace in Heaven.
*Qū*: The heavenly Brahman spirits flying above the Great Ultimate, riding the qi of the luminous wind, singing the melodies of the Cavern Chapters.
*Lì*: The name of a Jade Maiden of Supreme Harmony.
*Xiān*: *Xiānyún* (Auspicious Cloud).
*Pú*: The name of a tower in Heaven.
*Yù*: The hidden name of the Heavenly Emperor Lord.
*Zhēn*: Arrival. The *Yù* Emperor constantly rides the wheel of the eight luminaries, roaming beyond the eight poles, and returns with the ten-absolute numinous banner to summon heavenly demons and deliver heavenly beings. Those who constantly recite this Cavern Chapter will have flying heavens chant from afar, the Three Realms’ administrators welcome them, and their seven ancestors emerge from the eternal night to ascend to the Southern Palace.

*Dāluò Dàfàn*, *Sànyān Qìngyún*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Literary Elevation Heaven.

*Dā*: The name of a jade tower in Heaven.
*Luò*: The tower’s brilliance, resplendent and radiant.
*Dà*: At the inception of the kalpa’s transformation by the Heavenly Worthy of Great Pardon, a great amnesty is declared, called *Dàyòu*, emptying the Three Evil Paths and halting the trials of the Nine Dark Realms.
*Fàn*: The qi of Brahman conduct, inaugurating the Dragon Han kalpa and governing the era of Crimson Brightness.
*Sànyān*: Perfected Ones dispersing incense smoke at the Jade Pass.
*Qìngyún*: The five-colored auspicious clouds.

The auspicious clouds reach the Purple Palace, and flying heavens dance in the wheel of space.

The Azure Primordial says: When the Primordial Beginning first declared the great amnesty, the *Dāluò* palace courts released imprisoned souls.

*Fēisǎ Yùdū*, *Míngmó Shàngmén*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Māyā Heaven.

*Fēi*: The title of the Flying Heavenly Spirit King. When Heaven and Earth’s destiny changes and sinks into *Yánkāng*, darkness prevails without end. The Flying Heavenly Spirit illuminates and scatters radiance, and all heavens receive the sprinkled qi. In the Dragon Han kalpa, this occurs in an instant.
*Yù*: *Yùzhēn*, the sacred title of the one who opens the eternal night.
*Dū*: The *Fēngdū* of the Nine Dark Realms. If one has meritorious deeds, *Yùzhēn* opens the gates of the eternal night, and *Fēngdū* delivers them from the eight difficulties. The seven ancestors are reborn, and the dark souls regain their light.
*Míng*: Understanding the meaning of the eight characters.
*Mó*: The Demon King.
*Shàng*: The Supreme Emperor.
*Mén*: Those beneath the Straight Gate who can clearly comprehend the meaning of the eight characters will have the Demon King respectfully submit and the Supreme Emperor nurture them at the Gate of Initial Birth. Beneath the gate, the Lord Han oversees destiny and records in the Southern Palace, bestowing blessings upon the nine clans and granting grace in life and death.

*Wúxíng Shàngshǒu*, *Huízhí Liúxuán*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Transcendent Balance Heaven.

*Wú*: The Upper Dao. It speaks of the qi of the Primordial Beginning illuminating the unsurpassed Dao.
*Xíng*: The heavenly net of the primordial kalpa, encompassing the eight poles. Brahman qi pervades and flows ceaselessly.
*Shàngshǒu*: The Sin-Recording Palace of the Northern Dipper. When the celestial mechanism turns and the kalpa’s calculations converge, the numbers culminate, and the great kalpas intersect.
*Huí*: Turning.
*Zhí*: Treading. At the kalpa’s inception, the Primordial Beginning treads the void and turns the wheel, disseminating transformation across the ten directions.
*Liú*: Flowing with the light of the Three Dawns, illuminating the palace of the eternal night.
*Xuán*: Emptiness. The Transcendent Balance Heaven’s *Xuándū* has the Empty Peak Mountain, where the myriad sages roam and the living and dead return. If one’s Dao is insufficient and the body is destined for extinction, the soul ascends to the Empty Peak to undergo refinement and ascend to the Southern Palace.

*Ātuó Lóngluó*, *Sìxiàng Xūyuán*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the Veiled Heaven.

*Ā*: In Heaven, there is a nine-fold mountain range, connected in continuous ridges.
*Tuó*: The tower atop the mountain, reaching the radiance of the Jade Purity and overlooking the realms of the Three Worlds. The Emperor Lord often roams the ridges of *Āqiū*, monitoring the sins of the myriad beings.
*Lóng*: Dragon Mountain, nine hundred million miles from *Ātuó*.
*Luó*: The names of the sun and moon.

The peaks of *Luó* intertwine, where the sun and moon shine brightly above. The Four refers to the palaces of the Four Poles: East Florescence, South Ultimate, West Numinous, and North Perfected. The Perfected of the Four Poles govern the registers of life and death. *Xiàng* is the chariot of the Wheel of Symbols. The Perfected constantly ride these chariots, traversing the Three Realms to audit the records of beings’ lives and deaths, and to initiate and deliver learners.

*Xū* is the curved nurturing. The Heavenly Emperor’s taboo-name is the Southern Palace’s Lord of Life-Measurement, who oversees the refinement and deliverance of decayed souls. *Yuán* is the Emperor. He is the Youth Born at Midday, who pours essence upon the Heavenly People. Those who recite and chant the cavernous chapters will have their jade names inscribed in the Emperor’s register, their lives and deaths delivered at the Southern Palace, and the Four Poles will grant them natural feathered chariots, while their seven ancestors rejoice in ascending to the Hall of Blessings.

**Southern Eight Heavens**
*South Flaming* – *Yīnyàn* – *Cavern Floating* – *Jade Eyes Shimmering*
These eight characters are the inner sound of the Harmonious Yang Heaven.

*South Flaming*: In the south lies the Courtyard of Flowing Fire, its flying flames illuminating the eight directions. *Cavern Floating*: The Palace of Cavernous Yang, where the *qi* of flowing fire blazes and floats upward. *Jade Eyes*: The fat of flowing fire, which refines the body, generates jade radiance, and shines like pupils—hence called Jade Eyes. The Perfected of the South Ultimate preside within this palace. All learners who first attain the Dao proceed to the Courtyard of Flowing Fire, where the Perfected wash and refine them with the fire’s fat, scouring away the dust and filth.

*Shimmering*: Multitudinous. *Dharma-forms fall into emptiness, the Nine Numinous advance forward.*
These eight characters are the inner sound of the Reverent Florescence Heaven.

*Dharma-forms*: The title of the Primordial Heavenly Honored One during the Dragon Han kalpa. In the Red Clarity kalpa, he was called the Lord of Primordial Name; at the dawn of the Highest Sovereign’s reign, he was named the Primordial Venerable. His Dharma-body, transformed by the *qi* of Brahma, arises with the kalpas, manifesting as a single spirit without undergoing womb-birth. *Fall into emptiness*: The Primordial One arises from the void. *Nine Numinous*: The Nine Florescence Perfected, who govern the Upper Palace of South Prosperity and oversee the karmic confrontations of souls in the Nine Glooms. *Advance forward*: The Perfected, who manage the records of destiny, assess the merits of souls from past lives.

*Guān Fù* says: When the first *yin* arises, it is like cinnabar yielding mercury; true *yin* descends, resembling the moon’s image. Returning to the Central Palace, *yin* retreats to the Yang Chamber, and mercury hastens to merge with lead.

*Dù* and *Wū* are the Terrace of the Universal, *Green Net of the Great Thousand.*
These eight characters are the inner sound of the Ancestral Whirlwind Heaven.

*Dù*: A mountain name in Heaven, atop which lie the dens of myriad dragons and the Yellow Chambers. *Wū*: The inner sound of the Perfected of the True Dawn, who governs the Yellow Chambers, enduring the great kalpas without end and growing ever brighter through the Dragon Han. *Pú*: The hidden title of the Flying Heavenly Perfected, who number beyond count. *Terrace*: The Jade Terrace, situated on the southern side of Marsh Mountain. *Green Net*: Lady Luóyīng of the Moon, who administers the measures of the Great Yin, rides the *qi* of Brahma-conduct, and operates the Pass of Transformation in accord with the Heavenly Origin, without error. When the great kalpas converge, the sun and moon both assemble above the Jade Hall, awaiting the kalpa’s reopening to resume their transformations. *Great Thousand*: The reckoning of worlds. A thousand counted to a thousand is the Lesser Thousand; a thousand Lesser Thousands make a Middle Thousand; a thousand Middle Thousands make a Great Thousand. Those who recite and chant the cavernous chapters will ascend to the Yellow Chambers, wander within the Jade Terrace, and behold the realms of the Great Thousand.

*Vast and Nine Ugly, Sháo’s Songs and Yuán’s Circuit.*
These eight characters are the inner sound of the August Reed Heaven.

*Vast*: In the era of Extended Purity, the jade characters of Heavenly script were veiled and indistinct, faint and remote. *Vast*: When the Dragon Han kalpa began, its texts became bright again, vast and boundless. Upon encountering the true Dao, when the destiny of men and women reaches its limit and another kalpa passes, the nine *qi* each generate a beast to harm the wicked. Once the kalpa reopens, these nine beasts are called the Nine Ugly Ghosts. The Northern Emperor and the Upper Perfected govern the registers of life and death, thus establishing the Nine Ugly to assist the Three Officials. Their number culminates in eighty-one myriad, measuring the convergence of Heavenly *qi*. The Nine Ugly are titled the Nine Capital Envoys.

*Sháo*: The inner name of the Divine Sovereign of the August Reed Heaven. The Divine Sovereign of the Divine Empyrean is the spirit of the Demon King, who constantly tests learners of the Dao, discerning correctness from error. He composes songs to disturb the heart. Those whose hearts remain steadfast are then protected and promoted to ascend the August Reed Heaven. *Yuán* is another name for the Southern Dipper. *Zhān* is an alternate title for the Northern Dipper. Those with meritorious deeds are recorded by the Southern Dipper, which then delivers them from the trials of the Three Realms, rescues them from the sufferings of the Nine Glooms, and reports to the Demon King, who dares not harm or obstruct them. Those with evil deeds are recorded by the Three Officials and reported to the Northern Dipper, which then instructs the Demon King to annihilate their souls, consigning them to the depths of the Nine Glooms to toil through endless nights, never to emerge.

*Above the Clouds, Nine Capitals—Flying Life Soars Freely.*
These eight characters are the inner sound of the Hall Radiance Heaven.

*Above the Clouds*: The inner taboo-name of the Flying Heavenly Divine King. At the opening of the Dragon Han kalpa and the commencement of the Red Clarity kalpa, he unfolded the books of spontaneity and established the roots of Heaven and Earth. *Nine Capitals*: After the Three Symbols divided, there arose a nine-tiered terrace situated above the Jade Capital, resplendent amidst the Empty Mystery. The Flying Heavenly Divine People constantly scatter the incense of a hundred harmonies and the flowers of the five clouds to observe the Flying Heavenly Perfected. Upon the terrace stands the Grand Perfected Jade Youth, who thrice daily holds the banner of ten absolutes, circling once to summon the Heavenly Emperors of all heavens to thrice encircle the Mystic Terrace. Learners who constantly recite the cavernous chapters will have their flying lives open the path of deathlessness, where the *qi* of eternal life flows downward to refine the five souls, and the Eight Sceneries are preserved. *Soars Freely*: The Forest of Soaring. Learners who ascend the Mystic Terrace and wander the Forest of Soaring, their bodies adorned with Heavenly script and their mouths chanting the cavernous chapters, will eventually ascend to the Palace of the Empty Capital.

Amidst lush fragrance, the Dharma-wheel of Mara turns. The eight characters: *Duanjing*, the celestial sound within Heaven. *Na* is the name of the Attendant Gentleman of Heaven’s Center, who governs the *qi* of Heaven’s four seasons and the guiding principle of emptiness in Brahmanic conduct, thereby rectifying and stabilizing the divisions within Heaven. *Yu* is the name of the Heavenly Pass’s Hollow Wheel. *Yufu* is the name of the numinous youth within the Dipper, who constantly revolves the *Yu*-wheel to summon the Heavenly Perfected. When the Heavenly Pass turns ten times, the great sages of the ten directions ascend to pay court at the Jade Capital, and the myriad spirits assemble in unison as *Yufu* intones the rites. *Moluo* is the inner taboo-name of the Great Demon of Heaven’s Center. At *Yufu*’s first chant, the demon kings bind their forms. Learners who comprehend the *qi* of the four seasons and the ten revolutions of the Pass will, through the gate of the Eight Dharma-wheels, mount their chariots to ascend to Jade Purity and pay court at the Terrace of the Purple Tenuity.

*Haochi* holds the Mirrorless, gathering grace and moving countenance. The eight characters: *Gongqing*, the celestial sound within Heaven. *Hao* is the inner name of the Celestial Inspector-General. *Chi* is the name of the Dragon Abyss, wherein the host of dragons coils, circulating the blossoms of the Eastern Well to bathe the Heavenly Perfected—this is the essence of the Yellow Blossom of the Moon, pouring its flow into the Eastern Well. *Wujing* is the Flying Heavenly Divine King, who emits light of no-color, oversees the registers of life and death, and initiates learners. *Guān Fù* says: From the hour of *shen* to the hour of *geng* is called "half a catty of water," when yin returns to the yang chamber, and the future casts its lead; its substance dissolves and becomes silver. *Lanzi* is the name of the Three Realms’ Gate. Those who know this name will have the demon kings open the palace of the Long Night, releasing the souls of the Nine Darks to pass through the Three Realms’ Gate. *Yunrong* is the name of the Jade Maiden of Mystic Harmony. Those who pass through the Three Realms’ Gate will have *Yunrong* guide their forms with the *qi* of Vermilion Mound and bathe their spirits with the fluid of Great Harmony, ascending to the Hall of Blessings.

Fragrance luminous and vast, the divine tassel self-purifies. The eight characters: *Jiyao*, the celestial sound within Heaven. *Fulang* is another name for the Terrace of the Jade Capital within Heaven’s Center, where the Western Numinous Perfected constantly recites the cavernous chapters to wander above it. *Kuoyi* is the inner name of the Heavenly Divine Duke, born together with the Primordial Beginning as the model of Mystic *Qi*, teaching those who study immortality. Those who master the sound of the eight characters will have the Divine Duke open the door of the Long Night and enter the gate of rebirth, thereby ascending the Terrace of the Jade Capital. *Shenying* is the Numinous Youth of the Purple Tenuity, who governs the corpses of the deceased. If one sings the boundless chapters of the Divine Tassel, one will return one’s form to the chamber of the Three Refinements, receive the *qi* of spontaneity, and enjoy limitless distant years.

The Eight Heavens of the West: *Daoli Chanyou, Poni Gao Tong*. The eight characters: *Kongsheng*, the celestial sound within Heaven. *Daoli* is the name of the Boundless World of the South, where the kingdom of Chan is *Daoli*, also called Chanli. Within that land stands the Palace of Cavernous Yang and the Courtyard of Flowing Fire. The numinous scripture begins in the Flowing Fire; after refinement and enlightenment, the kingdom of *Daoli* is transformed into the Hall of Blessings and Virtue. *You* is the inner name of the Lord of Compassion in the Upper South. *Poni* is the name of the numinous youth of the Fire-Refinement Pool. Those who pass through the Palace of Cavernous Yang all proceed to the Fire Pool for refinement, reborn in the Hall of Blessings and Virtue. *Gaotong* is the spirit of the demon kings of the *Daoli* world, who constantly obstruct the path of life. Those who know the name of the Lord of Compassion and proceed to the Numinous Youth for refinement will be reborn in the land of Blessings and Virtue, where the demon kings’ spirits submit. Those who recite the sound of the eight characters will have the primordial and ultimate numinous officials of the *Daoli* world guard their bodies, swiftly arriving at the Southern Palace, where immortals await to welcome them. Within three years, they will surely ride the cinnabar clouds’ wheel to ascend to the Heaven of the Three *Qi*.

*Wansou Dise*, the Hall of the Great Vast. The eight characters: *Huangya*, the celestial sound within Heaven.

The *Wansou* is the inner name of the Emperor of the *Huangya* Heaven. He presides over the *Scripture of the Great Wilderness*, illuminating the text of the eight characters. *Dise* is the name of a *Feitian* Perfected of the Form Realm, who constantly rides a chariot drawn by dragons, moving in and out of the Jade Purity, delivering those of good root. The *Hall of the Great Vast* is the Hall of Transformation and Birth, where the transformation of the empty and cavernous coalesces into natural chapters, vast and boundless, opening the passage for the deliverance of all beings. When practitioners master the sound of the eight characters, the *Feitian* Perfected descends in a cloud chariot to bear their bodies upward into the Hall of Transformation and Birth.

*Liuluo Fanmeng*, *Jingwei Xiaoyu*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Ji Feng* Heaven. *Liu* is the inner name of a Heavenly King. *Luo* is the taboo name of the Moon Maiden, who presides over the rites of feasting and revelry, streaming radiance through the *Ji Feng* Heaven and illuminating the true essence of the Nine Mysteries. *Fan* is the name of a *Feitian* Perfected, who governs the turning of the Nine Heavens’ gates. *Meng* is the name of the Primordial Heavenly Deity, who rectifies the *fan qi*, delivers celestial and human beings, and secures the root of the *Ji Feng*. *Guanfu* says: *Gen* is earth, the foundation of generation and completion, the root of creation and transformation. *Jing* is the *Jing Huang*, a Perfected of the Four Poles. *Wei* is *Wei Xiu*, a transcendent of the *Jingxiao* Heaven, who together govern the *Jade Capital Terrace*, reviewing and delivering the souls of good root in the long night. *Xiao* is *Ren*, the palace of the *White Primordial Sovereign*. *Yu* is the *Xiao Ren*’s *Yu*, the place of receiving guests. Those who constantly recite the cavernous chapters will ride the nine-colored clouds to ascend the *Jing Huang*’s terrace.

*Yi Miao Wu Ji*, *Wanshou Shaodu*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Xiao Mang* Heaven. *Yi Miao* is the title of the Heavenly King of *Xiao Mang*. *Wu Ji* is the courtyard of emptiness and stillness, for this Heavenly King has come from the *Dragon Han* and emerged in the *Red Brightness*, dwelling in the still courtyard within emptiness. *Wanshou* is the inner title of the *Supreme Dao Lord*, who constantly expounds the profound mysteries of the Primordial Beginning to deliver beings. *Shaodu* is the name of the *Numinous Youth of the Sun’s Center*, who scatters solar essence to irrigate the body’s streams and scatters flying blossoms to brush away dust. When practitioners know the sound of the eight characters, the Heavenly King descends in a chariot of radiant clouds, bearing them above the Three Realms into the still courtyard.

*A Lan Yu Zhu*, *Hua Mo Yan You*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Weng Chong* Heaven. *A Lan* is the hidden name of a Heavenly King, who constantly rides the wheel of radiant clouds, roaming the nine-tiered terrace, dwelling in the jade tower, chanting cavernous chapters to subdue the demon hosts. *Yu* is the hidden name of a demon king in the *Yu Mo* Heaven. *Zhu* is the Desire Realm, where the demon king *Yu Bo* constantly dwells above, chanting and intoning the empty ballads. *Hua* is the radiant splendor of the Form Realm. *Mo* is the vast and boundless Desire Realm, unsearchable. *Yan* is the courtyard that binds ghosts, and *You* is the chamber that restrains them. When the Heavenly King ascends the cloud tower and intones the boundless chapters, the heavenly demons respond and bind themselves, while the myriad ghosts encounter *You* and submit their forms. Those who submit to him will see their nine ancestors flourish, and those who cultivate this will see their ashen bones reborn.

*Jiu Kai Zi Bian*, *A Na Pin Shou*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Jiang You* Heaven. *Jiu Kai* refers to the great unfolding at the beginning, when heaven and earth were not yet divided, and the revolving Three *Qi* opened into nine parts. Once the nine degrees were clarified, the nine positions were arrayed, and the ten thousand kinds of yin and yang were born, naturally discerning and distinguishing. *A* is the inner name of the *A Qiu* Heavenly King, who constantly rides a dragon chariot to ascend the ridge of Dragon Mountain, roaming and observing within the Nine Mysteries. *Na* is the hidden name of the *Na Xie* *Feitian* divine person, who flies through the Three Realms, reviewing the long night and delivering the souls of the good. Those who know the sound of the eight characters will have the Heavenly King assess and deliver their bodies, entering the foremost ranks of the flying transcendent hosts, transforming their decayed bones into the countenance of youths.

*Wu Liang Fu Gai*, *Fu Luo He Shen*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Ruan Le* Heaven. *Wu Liang* is the first divine being among the boundless great deities of heaven, who governs all the flying transcendent deities, for all receive their assessment from him and thereby ascend and advance. *Fu* is the inner name of the *Gengsheng* Perfected, who constantly reviews the records of the dark night and examines the roots of good and evil. *Gai* is the title of the *Xuan Zhong* Hall of Blessings. *Fu* refers to the souls of the dark night, who receive deliverance from the Perfected and are thus called *floating*. *Luo* is the *Great Luo*, who opens the great thousand worlds, summoning the guests of rebirth to ascend to the *Great Luo* Heaven and determine their registers, erasing death. *He* is *He Qing* (Joined Celebration). *Shen* is the *Divine Duke*, the minister of the *Great Luo*. Those who know the sound of the eight characters will join in celebration with the Divine Duke and receive deliverance as guests of rebirth.

*Yu Dan Chang Sang*, *Bai Kong Du Xian*. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Tan Shi* Heaven. *Yu Dan* is the name of the *Jade Capital* in the *Tan Shi* Heaven. *Chang Sang* is the *Qian Lin* (Soaring Grove) in heaven, also called the *Sang Lin* (Mulberry Grove). The *Qian Lin* shades the *Eastern Florescence* Palace, and upon its leaves are the great cavernous chapters, written in purple jade script, resplendent in the *Upper Clarity*. When the divine wind stirs, the cavernous chapters resound—hence *Bai Kong* (Cypress Void). *Du Xian* refers to the flying transcendent divine persons who review the registers of life and death for those who study immortality, delivering the souls of the Nine Darks and ascending them into the gate of the *Dharma Wheel*.

The Eight Heavens of the North:
*Jue Wu Zi Yu*, *Jiu Ri Dao Qian*.

The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Xiao Du* Heaven. *Jue Wu* refers to the divine beings of the *Dragon Han* era, the flying transcendent gods. From the primordial qi of the *Original Beginning*’s initial unfolding, within the boundless, formless *Ming Xing*, *Jue Wu* emerged borne by the currents, coalescing qi to take form. Once the Nine Heavens of *Xiao* were established, they withstood the unending kalpas. *Yu* is the inner name of the Heavenly King of *Xiao Du*. The *Nine* signifies that the *Yu* King rides a chariot drawn by elephant wheels, traversing the Nine Mysteries’ gates, revolving the Nine Mechanisms’ measures, aligning with the kalpa’s appointed time. The *Sun* refers to the solar youths within heaven who guide and harmonize qi; when the celestial revolution ends, the solar youths halt their radiance, delivering and refining the scholars, anointing them with the essence of the *Water Mother*, guiding them with the qi of *Great Harmony*, purifying the Five Spirits, and ushering them into the *Vermilion Palace*.

*Guan Fu* says: *Qian* is the beginning of the myriad things, the spontaneous void, the pure and true unified qi, called the *Empty Qi Golden Womb*. It is likened to silver ore, concealed within the kidneys, termed the *Original Spirit*. As this qi transforms and returns to the *Central Palace*, it becomes the *Elixir Mother*, propelled by the *Metal Duke*. *Metal* is the qi of the primordial, spontaneous *Way*, the *Golden Womb*. *Fire* is the yang qi of daily arising and flourishing. Returning to the root and restoring the origin is called *silver*. The *Kun Mother* covers the east, her form gathering the *Upper Mystery*.

The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Yuan Dong* Heaven. The *Kun Mother* is the governor of the *Grand Yin*’s capital, the *Nine Numinous Immortal Mother*. She oversees the *Eastern Sea*’s *Fu Sang* and the *Yang Valley*’s abyss, perpetually managing the earth’s mechanisms, revolving the primordial qi, ascending to respond to the *Celestial Pass*. When the *Celestial Pass* turns, the earth’s mechanisms move, and once the heavens complete a revolution, the waters surge and overflow three thousand three hundred times. Thus, the qi of heaven and earth intermingle, the nine seas become misty and vast, and a single water pervades the heavens. The *East* is where the *Eastern Sea* receives convergence, controlling the river’s source. The *Covering* refers to the water spirit who governs *Kunlun Mountain*, reinforcing the great seas, damming the *Eastern Well*, ensuring the earth’s mechanisms do not sink, and preserving the kalpa’s enduring existence.

*Guan Fu* says: *Kun* is the completion of the myriad things. After conception, the spirit is concealed within the kidneys, called the *Kun Palace*. It is both nature and lead, returning to the *Central Palace* in motion. The transforming mechanism is the daily arising yang qi, serving as the foundation of the elixir. The *Medicinal Ancestor* gathers cinnabar and mercury to form the elixir’s substance. As for creation, it arises from nothing into being; thus, *Kun* is established through *Qian*, and *Qian* is completed through *Kun*. *Qian* and *Kun* mutually engender and perfect one another, with no precedence of before or after. It is like lead arising from silver, and silver being perfected through lead. The *Form Gathering* occurs at the time of fixed union, when the *Kun Mother*’s form emerges above the *Eastern Sea*, summoning the *Bird Mother* and welcoming the immortality-seeking scholars with phoenix chariots to the wilds of *Kunlun*. The *Bird Mother* is the spirit overseeing the water’s conditions. The *Upper* refers to the *Kun Mother* ascending to the *Celestial Lord*, reporting the kalpa’s appointed time, delivering the immortality-seeking scholars, and inscribing their names in the *Mysterious Capital*.

*Guan Fu* says: When the first yang returns, the wondrous transforming qi arises from the *Kun Palace*. The true yang ascends like the sun’s image, reaching the *Central Palace*, where the *Metal Mother* gathers it—this is called *cinnabar*. *Cinnabar* is wood; wood is the dragon. This is the *Azure Dragon* receiving the talisman.

*Tuo Luo Yu Miao*, the ethereal qi merges with the clouds. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Miao Cheng* Heaven. *Tuo* is the inner name of the *Celestial Emperor*, who resides with the *Miao Cheng* Heaven on the *Cloud Al* Ridge. *Luo* is the name of the moon at its first crescent, embracing the moon to shine upon the *Cloud Ridge*. *Yu* is the name of the divine king of the *Miao Cheng* Heaven. Also, *Yu* means *birth*, summoning the flying transcendent gods of the ten directions. *Miao* is the name of the *Feathered Forest* overseer in heaven, a divine king who perpetually assists in governing the Three Realms, reviewing the registers of human life and death, commanding demon kings to protect and recommend those who attain the Dao. *Shao* means *distant and lofty*. Those who are delivered and protected ascend to the *Feathered Forest* overseer, receive talismans, and ascend to heaven, traversing the cloud palaces in lofty flight. *Qi* is the cloud qi. *He* means *merging with the radiance*. Having entered the *Feathered Forest*, they weave cloud qi into garments, ascend to the *Vermilion Palace*, and then merge with the radiance of all heavens to soar upward.

The *Flying Transcendents’ Great Ugly One* oversees the heavens above. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Jin Shang* Heaven. The *Flying Transcendents* are the divine kings of the flying transcendents in the ten directions. The flying and mysterious qi within heaven coalesce into the *Empty Cavern Scriptures*, which the flying transcendent divine kings perpetually recite to receive the scholars. The *Great Ugly One* is the registrar of the Three Realms, overseeing the charts of life and death. *Ugly* means *elder*. The great demons of the Three Realms serve the *Great Ugly One*. If scholars know this sound, demon kings will protect their authenticity, and their bodies will ascend to the *Three Clarities*. The *General* is the official who oversees the flying transcendents, governing the qi of the eight assemblies to hasten the heavens’ and earth’s revolutions, and presiding over the officials of the long night to deliver the souls of the *Nine Darks*. Those who know the sounds within heaven will have demon kings submit their names, and the *Great Ugly One* will inscribe them in the *Immortal Capital*, ascending to the *Jin Shang* Heaven.

*Sha Tuo Jie Liang*, the *Dragon Han*’s radiant freshness. The eight characters are the inner sound of the *Chang Rong* Heaven. *Sha* is the *Sha Lan Palace* within heaven, a detached palace of the *Purple Tenuity*. *Tuo* is *Tuo Qiu Mountain*. The multitudes of *Tuo Qiu*, numbering in the hundreds of millions, are all newly delivered and refined individuals whose merits are not yet complete, lingering and dispersing therein. *Jie Liang* refers to when the kalpa’s revolution converges; the multitudes of *Tuo Qiu* calculate their merits and measure their virtues, ascending to *Zhu Lu* to receive blessings and immortality. *Dragon Han* is the name of the initial kalpa. *Ying* is the name of the flying transcendent divine king of the initial kalpa, who perpetually delivers the souls of the dark realms, ascending them to the *Sha Lan Palace*. *Xian* is the youth of the *Southern Palace*. When scholars attain deliverance, the immortal youths guide and refine them upon the *Vermilion Mound*.

*Bi Luo Fu Li*, the empty songs preserve the treasures.

The Eight Characters are the inner sounds of *Yu Long Heaven*. *Bi* refers to the ever-arising azure *qi* within *Yu Long Heaven*. *Luo* is the name of a flying transcendent deity who, thrice daily, leads the host of celestial sages to ascend and pay homage at the *Seven Treasures Palace*. *Fu Li* is the inner name of the Heavenly King; when the host of sages ascends to pay homage, the Heavenly King proclaims jubilation. *Kong* is the name of the celestial chamberlain. *Ge* refers to the cavernous hymns; when the chamberlain utters a single cry, numinous winds harmonize, and the sound forms the cavernous hymns—hence called *Kong Ge*. *Bao Zhen* means that if scholars comprehend the sound of these Eight Characters, they ascend to the *Southern Palace* as guests of the flying transcendents, preserving themselves through the unending kalpas and treasuring the natural script—thus called *Bao Zhen*.
