chunks.original_text: 赤天魔王姓佛，名由肃。 白天魔王姓赤，名张市。 黑天魔王姓徐，名直事。 黄天魔王姓天门，名波狂。 皆主人贪欲，耗摇神气，障败道缘，故曰魔王。 五帝大魔即五天之下魔王也。 居万神之首，是曰宗也。 即人身五官也。 《玉清隐书》云：五帝魔王领官属，与天同生，常恼乱学道之士，不欲成功。 又自矜於诸天上帝，齐其圣功。 后因龙汉开图，乃服元始之化。 故《步虚颂》曰：魔王敬受事，故能朝诸天。 此言魔王作歌，以败乱学者。 自服元始之化而后专职魔试而已，飞行鼓从，总领鬼兵，言其飞行三界，鼓率部领鬼兵侍从也。 麾幢鼓节，自号赫奕。 言其麾扬旛幢，鼓舞旌节，游观乎太空之上，自号赫奕之功，与诸天齐也。 上天度人，严摄北酆者，即北都罗酆也。 上天开度人之功，先严戒北酆鬼官，不得遏算绝命，承天尊开度顺化而行，敕摄鬼帝，普告冥关，宣约示禁，则无辄肆害於末学矣。 神公受命，普扫不祥者，幽栖曰：神公者，大罗 无极神公也。 神公受敕命，五帝大魔扫除不祥，护卫学者。 大魔承命以八威神龙吐毒而收邪，猛马驾车而四布，天丁秉命前驱，大帅仗旛后从，火铃大将掷火万里，火焰八冲。 敢有干试，拒遏上真者，敢有拒遏上帝之敕命者也。 前则金钺行戮，后则巨天之斧施刑，屠割鬼精，妖爽之干试，如风火之疾，不暂停也。 神威所至，千千截首，万万剪形，皆不留踪矣。 以至魔试无所干犯，鬼魂灭其妖精，学者至是则功圆道备，内外一如。 三宫北酆明检鬼营，不得容隐； 金马驿程三官九府。 北都罗酆，皆考校世人幽明罪福，善恶之司，明检鬼营罪录，黑籍应有。 学士宿业重，殃先亡祖襧，未蒙原宥者，不得容隐停滞，咸与蠲除。 驿马呈上而逍遥上清矣。 普告无穷，万神咸听，徧告十方三界，咸使知闻，悉遵天尊命令。 三界五帝、诸天大魔列言保举，驰奏上清矣。 默庵曰：此言受度之人，天门不得拘阻，魔鬼不得干试是也。 元始无量度人上品妙经通义卷之二竟 元始无量度人上品妙经通义卷之三

The Red Heaven Demon King’s surname is Fo, his given name Yousu. The White Heaven Demon King’s surname is Chi, his given name Zhangshi. The Black Heaven Demon King’s surname is Xu, his given name Zhishi. The Yellow Heaven Demon King’s surname is Tianmen, his given name Bokuang. All preside over greed and desire, depleting and agitating the spirit’s qi, obstructing and corrupting the conditions of the Dao—hence they are called Demon Kings. The Five Great Demon Emperors are the Demon Kings beneath the Five Heavens. Dwelling at the head of the myriad spirits, they are called the Ancestors. They correspond to the five sense organs of the human body.

The *Hidden Writ of Jade Clarity* states: "The Five Demon Emperors command their officials and subordinates, born together with Heaven, and constantly harass those who study the Dao, unwilling to see them succeed. They further boast before the Celestial Emperors of the various heavens, equating their sagely achievements. Later, during the Dragon Han era when the charts were revealed, they submitted to the transformation of the Primordial Beginning. Thus the *Hymn of Pacing the Void* says: 'The Demon Kings respectfully receive their duties, and thus are able to attend upon the various heavens.' This speaks of the Demon Kings composing songs to disrupt and confuse scholars. After submitting to the transformation of the Primordial Beginning, they thereafter specialized solely in testing through demonic trials. Flying and drumming, they lead their ghostly troops—this speaks of their flight through the Three Realms, drumming and commanding their ghostly soldiers as attendants. Waving banners and beating drums, they style themselves as resplendent. This speaks of their brandishing of flags and banners, dancing with standards and drums, roaming and observing above the Great Void, proclaiming their resplendent merit equal to that of the various heavens."

When the heavens deliver humankind, they strictly command the Northern Feng—namely, the Northern Capital of Luo Feng. When the heavens open to deliver humankind, they first sternly admonish the ghostly officials of the Northern Feng, forbidding them to cut short lifespans or sever destinies. Following the transformative edicts of the Heavenly Worthy, they issue commands to the Ghostly Emperors, universally proclaiming to the gates of darkness, announcing restrictions and prohibitions, so that no harm may be wantonly inflicted upon beginning scholars. The Divine Lords receive their mandate and universally sweep away inauspiciousness.

Youxi says: "The Divine Lords are the Great Simplicity’s Boundless Divine Lords." When the Divine Lords receive their edict, the Five Great Demon Emperors sweep away inauspiciousness to protect and guard scholars. The Great Demons, bearing their mandate, employ the eight mighty divine dragons to spew poison and subdue evil, while fierce horses draw their chariots to spread in all four directions. Heavenly soldiers wield their orders at the vanguard, great marshals brandish banners in the rear, and the fire-ringing generals hurl fire for ten thousand miles, flames surging in eight directions. Should any dare to test or resist the perfected of the Supreme, should any dare to oppose the edicts of the Celestial Emperors, the golden axes will execute them at the front, while the colossal axes of the Vast Heaven mete out punishment at the rear. The slaughter of ghostly essences and the destruction of demonic specters who dare to test or resist proceed like wind and fire, never ceasing for even a moment. Wherever the divine might reaches, thousands upon thousands are beheaded, myriads upon myriads have their forms obliterated, leaving no trace behind. Thus, demonic trials dare not trespass, and ghostly spirits are stripped of their spectral manifestations. Scholars who reach this point achieve perfection of merit and completion of the Dao, with inner and outer in perfect unity.

The Three Officials of the Northern Feng clearly inspect the ghostly camps, permitting no concealment. The Golden Horse relays the message through the Three Officials and Nine Bureaus. The Northern Capital of Luo Feng, which examines the hidden and manifest transgressions, blessings, and misfortunes of the world’s people, clearly inspects the ghostly camps’ records of sins and the black registers of those who are due. If a scholar’s accumulated karmic burden is heavy, and the calamities of their deceased ancestors have not yet been absolved, they shall not be allowed to remain concealed or stagnant, but shall all be purged and removed. The post-horses present their cases, and they ascend to roam in the Supreme Clarity. Universally proclaimed without end, all spirits heed the command, and the message is spread throughout the ten directions and the Three Realms, so that all may know and obey the Heavenly Worthy’s decrees. The Five Emperors of the Three Realms and the Great Demon Kings of the various heavens report and recommend, hastening to memorialize the Supreme Clarity.

Mo’an says: "This speaks of those who receive deliverance—Heaven’s gates may not detain or obstruct them, and demonic ghosts may not test or interfere with them." *The Supreme Primordial’s Wondrous Scripture of the Upper Chapters on Delivering Humankind, with Unlimited Meanings*, Scroll the Second, concludes. *The Supreme Primordial’s Wondrous Scripture of the Upper Chapters on Delivering Humankind, with Unlimited Meanings*, Scroll the Third.

chunks.original_text: 正一嗣教道合无为阐祖光范真人领道教事四十三代天师张宇初注 元洞玉历，龙汉延康，眇眇亿劫，混沌之中。 少微曰：此论劫运成坏，故有龙汉延康之旨。 《龟山玄录》云：元洞，上皇炁也。 天尊结元洞之炁，为玉历之书，以龙汉劫为初劫，开图曰赤明，劫终曰延康。 劫循环无穷，终而复始，劫终之后，三界空坏，万物精爽，长在太空，故曰延康，为坏劫之称。 赤明为开图之始。 《九品经》曰：昔混元溟涬，诸天未分，元始肇形，五劫初化，乃命梵元祖晨道君，肇录天元，运乘五劫。 故元洞者，以成祖炁； 玉历者，以纪天元。 自一炁化分，三因成九，若龙若蜒，蟠曲九道，漠漠无极，总九阳祖炁之元，太上乃运梵合炁，开始青天元祖炁。 故东方得九炁以分天境，劫号龙汉； 南方得三炁以分天境，劫号赤明； 中央得十二炁以分天境，劫号上皇； 西方得七炁以分天境，劫号延康； 北方得五炁以分天境，劫号开皇。 五劫既周，昊天成象，一炁混道，八景流光，八帝示形，九霄分化，结元洞五阳之炁为玉历，乃命天真皇人以玉历纪元洞之初，劫运流复之本，天真天民学仙功绩，升退之道。 夫元洞者，元始大洞之祖炁也。 由祖炁结而成玉历。 天真皇人按笔以纪劫运之数，始於龙汉，终於延康，历劫之久，成坏非； 一聚散不常，散而复聚，仍归于混沌之中。 不知其几千万亿，眇眇而不可穷也。 上无复色，下无复渊。 风泽洞虚，金刚乘天。 天上天下，无幽无冥，无形无影，无极无穷，溟涬大梵，寥廓无光。 默庵曰：此引龙汉祖劫之事，以启赤明第二劫开图之旨也。 龙汉之劫，既坏天地，上下皆非色象可见也。 严东曰：每劫运终，三光晦冥，天地混沌，上有何色，下有何渊是矣。 薛幽栖曰：风泽者，道之炁。 金刚者，精之炁。 道炁至柔则洞洽於虚，精炁至刚则运乘於天。 萧观复曰：风者，有炁无形。 泽者，有形无质。 乃虚无自然之理，所谓道之炁是矣。 金者，亘古今不变； 刚者，坚贞不坏，是纯真至妙之精，所谓精之炁是矣。 幽冥者，阴境也。 穷极者，边际也。 溟涬者，天地未分之初也。 劫运既终，天地虽大，皆形气所有，亦随劫迁革，是以上下不可以色渊求矣。 惟风泽之炁，空洞虚无，金刚不坏，天地之炁乘之以运行，犹天行健也。 乾刚内运，阴翳渐除，是以天上天下，混沌一炁，亦无幽冥，亦无形影，运行不息，亦无穷极矣。 溟溟涬涬，若天地未分之先； 胚腪磅礡，皆大梵之炁周流。 寥廓者，八极之表，不可名状，故曰无光。 其光内蕴而未明也。 修炼之士，视身如沤泡，终有生灭，采先天真一之炁，於父母未生之前，犹天地溟涬初判，再禀乾金至刚之炁，以成金胎，是为一灵妙有，历劫长存。 虽劫运变迁，三界消坏，万有俱空，而此性居洞虚之妙，独立而不改，周行而不殆是也。 则其自强不息，宜无有穷极矣。 大梵之炁内结而为丹基，寥廓无际，含光不曜，，乃阴阳之初判，阴尽而后阳纯矣。 赤明开图，运度自然。 元始安镇，敷落五篇。 赤书玉字，八威龙文。 保制劫运，使天长存。 默庵曰：外四篇，前四天是也； 中一篇，后四天是也。 赤明者，劫名也。 青元曰：至赤明之初，大运启图，玉历定纪，天地再开，於是天地、日月、星辰、山川物象，一时分判，昼夜寒暑四时推迁，罔有差忒。
chunks.translated_text:
The Orthodox Unity Lineage, Transmitting the Dao and Harmonizing Non-Action, Illuminating Ancestral Models and Exemplary Perfected, the Forty-Third Celestial Master Zhang Yuchu, Annotator of the *Original Cavern’s Jade Chronicle*:

In the *Jade Chronicle of the Original Cavern*, the Dragon Han and Yan Kang eras stretch across boundless kalpas, within the primordial chaos.

Shaowei says: "This discusses the kalpic cycles of formation and dissolution, hence the principles of the Dragon Han and Yan Kang eras." The *Mysterious Record of Mount Gui* states: "The *Original Cavern* is the qi of the Supreme Sovereign. The Heavenly Worthy condensed the qi of the *Original Cavern* to compose the *Jade Chronicle*, taking the Dragon Han kalpa as the first kalpa, its inception named *Red Clarity*, and its conclusion *Yan Kang*. The kalpic cycles are endless, ending only to begin anew. After a kalpa’s end, the Three Realms dissolve and all things’ essences and spirits abide in the Great Void—hence *Yan Kang*, the designation for the kalpa of dissolution. *Red Clarity* marks the beginning of the cosmic chart."

The *Scripture of the Nine Grades* says: "Of old, in the primordial darkness, when the myriad heavens were undivided, the Primordial Beginning first took form, and the five kalpas commenced transformation. Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy commanded the Venerable Lord of the Dawn Dao to initiate the celestial records, governing the five kalpas. Thus, the *Original Cavern* embodies the qi of formation, while the *Jade Chronicle* records the celestial origins. From the singular qi’s division, the Three Causes coalesced into the Nine, coiling like dragons or serpents through the nine paths, boundless and infinite—all comprising the primordial qi of the Nine Yangs. The Supreme One then harmonized the Brahma qi to inaugurate the ancestral qi of the Azure Heaven. Hence, the East received nine qi to divide the celestial realm, its kalpa named *Dragon Han*; the South received three qi to divide the celestial realm, its kalpa named *Red Clarity*; the Center received twelve qi to divide the celestial realm, its kalpa named *Supreme Sovereign*; the West received seven qi to divide the celestial realm, its kalpa named *Yan Kang*; the North received five qi to divide the celestial realm, its kalpa named *Kai Huang*. Once the five kalpas had run their course, the August Heaven took form. The singular qi merged with the Dao, the Eight Radiant Sceneries streamed with light, the Eight Emperors manifested, and the Nine Empyreans branched forth. The qi of the Five Yangs of the *Original Cavern* congealed into the *Jade Chronicle*, whereupon the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign was commanded to record the *Original Cavern*’s inception, the kalpic cycles’ revolving origins, and the merits of the Heavenly Perfected and Heavenly People in their cultivation of immortality, along with the paths of ascent and retreat."

Now, the *Original Cavern* is the ancestral qi of the Great Cavern of the Primordial Beginning. From this ancestral qi, the *Jade Chronicle* was formed. The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign wielded the brush to record the kalpic reckonings, beginning with *Dragon Han* and ending with *Yan Kang*. Through kalpas of immeasurable duration, formation and dissolution alternate—once dispersed, they reunite, returning to the primordial chaos. Countless hundreds of millions of kalpas pass, boundless and unfathomable. Above, no further colors remain; below, no further abysses endure. Wind and marsh pervade the void; adamantine qi rides the heavens. Between heaven above and heaven below, no darkness or obscurity, no form or shadow, no limits or bounds—only the vast Brahma, the expansive and lightless.

Mo’an says: "This cites the affairs of the ancestral *Dragon Han* kalpa to introduce the principle of *Red Clarity*, the second kalpa’s cosmic inception." In the *Dragon Han* kalpa, once heaven and earth were dissolved, above and below could no longer be perceived through form or image.

Yan Dong says: "At each kalpa’s end, the Three Luminaries darken, heaven and earth merge into chaos—what colors remain above, what abysses below?"

Xue Youqi says: "Wind and marsh are the qi of the Dao. Adamantine is the qi of essence. When the Dao’s qi is utterly yielding, it pervades the void; when the essence’s qi is utterly firm, it governs the heavens." Xiao Guanfu says: "Wind is qi without form; marsh is form without substance—this is the principle of spontaneous non-being, the so-called qi of the Dao. *Gold* endures unchanged through past and present; *adamantine* remains unyielding and indestructible—this is the purest, most wondrous essence, the so-called qi of essence. *Obscurity* is the yin realm; *utmost extremity* is the boundary. *Primordial darkness* is the state before heaven and earth divided. Once a kalpa ends, though heaven and earth are vast, all forms and qi are subject to transformation. Thus, above and below can no longer be sought through color or abyss. Only the qi of wind and marsh, empty and void, and the indestructible adamantine qi, which the heavens’ qi rides in its revolutions, endure like the heavens’ ceaseless motion. As the firmness of Qian inwardly revolves, the yin shadows gradually dissipate. Thus, between heaven above and heaven below, the primordial qi merges into oneness—no obscurity, no form or shadow, ceaseless in its revolutions, without end or limit. Vast and boundless, as before heaven and earth divided; swelling and surging, all pervaded by the Brahma qi. *Expansive* lies beyond the Eight Extremities, indescribable—hence, it is said to be without light, its luminosity inwardly concealed yet unmanifest."

Cultivators regard the body as transient as bubbles, destined for arising and ceasing. They gather the primordial True One’s qi from before their parents’ birth, as when heaven and earth first divided from the primordial darkness, and further receive the Qian metal’s utterly firm qi to form the golden embryo. This is the wondrous existence of the singular spirit, enduring through kalpas. Though kalpas shift and the Three Realms dissolve, all things empty, this nature abides in the wondrous void, independent and unchanging, revolving without cease. Thus, its ceaseless self-strengthening knows no bounds. The Brahma qi inwardly congeals to form the foundation of the elixir, vast and boundless, containing light yet unradiant—this is the initial division of yin and yang, where yin exhausts itself and yang becomes pure.

*Red Clarity* unfolds the cosmic chart, and salvation proceeds spontaneously. The Primordial Beginning presides in tranquility, unfolding the Five Chapters. The *Red Script* in jade characters, the Eight Might’s dragon script, safeguard and regulate the kalpic cycles, ensuring heaven’s enduring existence.

Mo’an says: "The outer four chapters correspond to the former four heavens; the central chapter corresponds to the latter four heavens." *Red Clarity* is the name of a kalpa. Qingyuan says: "At the inception of *Red Clarity*, the great kalpic cycle unfolds the cosmic chart, the *Jade Chronicle* establishes its records, and heaven and earth reopen. Thereupon, heaven and earth, sun and moon, stars and constellations, mountains and rivers, and all phenomena divide at once. Day and night, cold and heat, the four seasons proceed in succession, without error or deviation."

chunks.original_text: 故曰：运度自然。 元始安镇者，祖炁复笔，安天镇地。 五篇者，元始出梵炁结形，成云篆天章，载妙元神真道五者，故曰五篇。 赤书玉字者，默庵曰：外篇镇外，赤书者，阳施朱，象日； 中篇镇中，玉字者，阴施白，象月。 又混洞赤文也，开图之后，赤文乃复宣布，刻玉为书，以安镇也。 八威龙文者，默庵曰：外四天，内四天、共八方，皆龙文。 又八龙之箓，能御伏妖异策役鬼神，是以其功用，可保制劫运之变更，而与天齐永矣。 人之有身，性命之道一焉。 然命有终尽，而性无沦坏，是以修持定慧者，深究死生之说，幽明之故，以至能尽性致命而后性根不灭蒂长存，直证七返九还之妙，纵经亿劫，其苦轮既灭，是为长生久视，后天而终矣。 梵黑弥罗，万范开张。 元纲流演，三十二天。 轮转无色，周回十方。 旋斗历箕，回度五常。 默庵曰：此言第二劫赤文再立，天地之功用也。 赤文再立，天地复位，万物复育，元始祖劫之梵炁，弥满包罗诸天之上。 含生品汇，由是一炁化生，开张显露，而后万物始备，梵炁流布，发而成文，’是为典模训诰，经藏文录，垂范无穷。 虽百千万条之广，皆梵炁之发育也。 由万范一张，纲纪遂立。 元纲者，若纲之有纲也。 范模既张，纲纪流演而不息，是以徧周三十二天，轮转至於无色之界，周回一匝，十方皆至，终而复始，元一息之间断，无不周徧矣。 旋斗历箕者，斗，中斗也，即心也。 箕，属东方艮寅之位，每岁立春则杓昏建於寅初，与天左旋，历始於箕，居其中而顺建十二辰。 五常者，五星也，不曰五行五星，而曰五常，斗运於中，五行各尽其功用，乃天地之常道也。 一岁十二辰周而复始，旋历斗箕之始，日月五星逆行周回三百六十五度。 斗柄指地，先天之真炁亦随斗柄内运，从九地发生万物矣。 人身一日之间，有一年之节炁，循历二十八宿二十四炁，七十二候六十四卦，以成周天之火候也。 以人身而测，天度阳生於子，至寅为三阳，象泰，由下田而上也。 渐历斗箕而周流六虚，皆己真一之炁，周回十方，循度五行之常道也。 以心中虚运行不息，无不轮转而至矣。 所谓动静无端，阴阳无始者是也。 三十五分，总炁上元。 八景冥合，炁入玄玄。 玄中太皇，上帝高真。 泛景太霞，啸咏洞章。 默庵曰：元者，首之上。 八景，即八节也。 四时四方，各有八景，所以合成八八六十四卦。 观复曰：三十五分，阴阳五行、二十八宿也。 考之都分尺部，亦曰测日月五星之行，分二十八宿之度，故曰三十五分，以日月合璧，五星连珠，攒簇二十八宿，是曰总炁分之，则为三十五； 总之则一炁也。 上元者，历法以上古十一月朔、夜半冬至，日月五星会於子，谓之上元。 八景者，即生神中三部八景也。 玄中太皇者，玄元始三炁中之三宝君，是为上帝高真太霞之景，梵清景三炁之上。 洞章即下文金真朗郁、啸咏而歌也。 修之於内，日月合璧。 则水火既济；
chunks.translated_text:
Thus it is said: "The kalpic measures unfold naturally." *Primordial Beginning presides in tranquility*—the ancestral qi resumes its brush, stabilizing heaven and anchoring earth. The Five Chapters: from the Primordial Beginning emerges the Brahman qi, shaping form into cloud-seal celestial script, bearing the five wondrous truths of the primordial spirit and the true Dao—hence the Five Chapters.

The *Red Script* in jade characters: Mo’an says, "The outer chapters stabilize the outer realms; the *Red Script*, yang’s vermilion manifestation, images the sun. The central chapter stabilizes the center; the *jade characters*, yin’s pale manifestation, images the moon." It is also the *Hundun Red Script*—after the cosmic chart’s unfolding, the Red Script is once more proclaimed, carved into jade as script to stabilize and anchor. The Eight Might’s dragon script: Mo’an says, "The former four heavens and the latter four heavens, together comprising the eight directions, are all dragon script." It is also the register of the eight dragons, capable of subduing demons and spirits, commanding ghosts and gods. By its efficacy, it safeguards and regulates the kalpic cycles’ transformations, enduring coeternal with heaven.

The human body possesses the singular Dao of nature and life. Yet life has its end, while nature knows no decay or ruin. Thus, those who cultivate concentration and wisdom delve deeply into the doctrines of life and death, the principles of the hidden and manifest, until they can fully realize their nature and fulfill their destiny—thereupon, the root of nature remains undying, its stem ever-abiding, directly attaining the wondrous subtleties of the seven returns and nine restorations. Though passing through kalpas uncounted, the wheel of suffering is extinguished—this is long life and enduring vision, transcending the posterior heaven.

The Brahman darkness of *Mīra* unfolds myriad patterns. The primordial net flows and evolves, spanning the thirty-two heavens. Revolving through the formless, it cycles through the ten directions. The Dipper whirls past the Winnowing Basket, traversing the five constants. Mo’an says: "This speaks of the second kalpa, when the Red Script is reestablished—the functioning of heaven and earth. With the Red Script’s reestablishment, heaven and earth resume their positions, all things are reborn, and the Brahman qi of the Primordial Beginning’s ancestral kalpa fills and envelops all heavens above. The host of living beings, the ten thousand categories, are thus transformed by a single qi, unfolding and manifesting—thereafter, the myriad things are complete. The Brahman qi flows and spreads, issuing forth as script—this becomes the canonical models, the teachings and admonitions, the scriptural treasuries and written records, serving as patterns without end. Though vast as a hundred thousand myriad threads, all arise from the Brahman qi’s generation."

From the unfolding of myriad patterns, the net’s principles are established. The *primordial net*—like a net’s master cord. Once the patterns are spread, the net’s principles flow and evolve without cease, thus pervading the thirty-two heavens, revolving even unto the formless realms, cycling through one circuit to reach all ten directions. Beginning and ending in turn, not a single breath of the primordial unity is interrupted—none is left unpervaded.

The Dipper whirls past the Winnowing Basket: the Dipper is the central Dipper, that is, the heart. The Winnowing Basket pertains to the *gen-yin* position of the east; at each year’s Beginning of Spring, the Dipper’s handle aligns at dusk with the start of *yin*, rotating leftward with heaven, beginning its traverse at the Winnowing Basket, dwelling at the center while sequentially establishing the twelve earthly branches. The five constants are the five planets—not called the five phases and five planets, but the five constants. The Dipper moves at the center, the five phases each fulfilling their functions—this is the constant Dao of heaven and earth. A year’s twelve earthly branches cycle and recommence; the Dipper traverses the Winnowing Basket’s beginning, the sun, moon, and five planets move in retrograde through three hundred sixty-five degrees. When the Dipper’s handle points to earth, the true qi of the prior heaven also follows the Dipper’s inner movement, arising from the ninefold earth to generate the myriad things.

Within a single day in the human body, there are the seasonal nodes of a year, cycling through the twenty-eight constellations, the twenty-four qi, the seventy-two pentads, and the sixty-four hexagrams to complete the celestial fire’s measures. Measuring by the human body, heaven’s yang arises at *zi*, reaching *yin* as the three yangs, imaging *Tai*, ascending from the lower field. Gradually traversing the Dipper and Winnowing Basket, it circulates through the six voids—all is one’s true unity qi, cycling through the ten directions, following the constant Dao of the five phases. With the heart’s emptiness revolving unceasingly, none fails to be reached by its turning. This is what is meant by "movement and stillness without origin, yin and yang without beginning."

Thirty-five divisions, the upper origin’s total qi. The eight luminous scenes merge in darkness, qi enters the profound profundity. Within the profound, the Grand August, the Highest Perfected. Floating upon the luminous rosy clouds, whistling and chanting the cavernous chapters. Mo’an says: "The *origin* is above the head. The eight scenes are the eight solar terms. The four seasons and four directions each have eight scenes, combining to form the sixty-four hexagrams." *Guan Fu* says: "The thirty-five divisions are the yin-yang, five phases, and twenty-eight constellations." Examining the *Du Fen Chi Bu*, it is also called measuring the movements of the sun, moon, and five planets, dividing the degrees of the twenty-eight constellations—hence the thirty-five divisions. When the sun and moon unite as a jade bi and the five planets align as strung pearls, clustering with the twenty-eight constellations, this is called the total qi’s division into thirty-five; in summation, it is one qi.

The *upper origin* refers to the ancient calendar’s eleventh-month new moon, the winter solstice at midnight, when the sun, moon, and five planets converge at *zi*—this is the upper origin. The eight scenes are the eight luminous scenes within the three sections of the *Scripture of Generating the Spirit*. The *Grand August within the profound* is the Three Treasure Lords within the three qi of the Primordial Profundity—these are the Highest Perfected of the luminous rosy clouds, above the three qi of the Brahman clarity’s scene. The *cavernous chapters* are the golden truths’ radiant luxuriance, whistling and chanting the songs below. Cultivating within, the sun and moon unite as a jade bi—then water and fire achieve harmony.

chunks.original_text: 五炁朝元，则铅汞擒制，乃夺天地之造化，攒簇炉鼎之中，循历二十八宿，行周天之火候，采药於冬至之首，夺一年之节，炁於一阳初动之始，是为总炁上元，故曰元者，首之上也。 一炁上升於泥丸，八节之气候皆冥合矣。 是以直入玄玄之中，恍惚杳冥，中之有精也。 而我元神祖炁会於太渊之顶，即上帝高真之泛景於三炁之上矣。 若太霞流彩，空洞成音，而啸咏欣悦，有自然之感也。 金真朗郁，流响云营。 玉音摄炁，灵风聚烟。 紫虚郁秀，辅翼万仙。 千和万合，自然成真。 默庵曰：自此句以下，至各有生门，乃高真之洞章也。 金真者，金精也。 乃天地之灵根，阴阳之祖炁，先天真一之精，至阳之炁。 玉音者，龙吟虎啸之声也。 紫虚者，中黄之宫也。 金母既归神室，丹基已兆，金胎已萌，真神明耀，晃如金精之朗彻，龙虎二弦之炁出火生水之时，玉音流响，灵风内鼓，则炁归神室，养成鄞鄂。 中黄土釜之中，紫光红彩，摄炁聚烟而后秀结成真，郁勃内外，万炁归真，若水朝宗，若车辐凑，神畅炁和。 千神和为一神，万炁合为一炁，莫非自然之理。 内合成真，此皆还丹至妙至神之机，非假有为而成也。 经曰：回风混合，百日功成。 契曰：经营养鄞鄂，凝神以成躯是也。 真中有神，长生大君，无英公子，白元尊神，太乙司命，桃康合延，执符把箓，保命生根。 真中有神者，即元神为性之本，以其曩劫不坏，是曰长生大君。 恍惚中之有物，杳冥中之有精，其精甚真，其中有信是也。 无英，肝神； 白元，肺神； 太乙乃百神之主，司命，心神； 桃康，合延，二肾之神。 古愚曰：总举四神而言者，谓金木不间隔，水火不相克也。 五神不言脾神，谓非中意，不能和合四象，则神在其中矣。 是以太乙居中，以象五行，全籍於土丹道中则坎纳戊土，离纳己土，是曰坎戊月精，离己日光。 水火之交姤，铅汞之投合，金木之合并，皆中意媒合之也。 修炼之工，至妙至神之机，不越乎五行顺逆之理而已。 人能合日用之顺境，以究颠倒之妙，四象和合，五行攒簇，则命蒂愈固，性根长生矣。 是为至真中之有至神也。 观复曰：真神保其性命，灵炁护其生根是也。 符箓者，以有象言之，则元始符命也。 内求无象，皆己之真炁也。 能执持不怠，则可保固元命，而死魂受度，复生根矣。 上游上清，出入华房，八冥之内，细微之中。 下镇人身，泥丸绛宫，中理五炁，混合百神，十转回灵，万炁齐仙。 默庵曰：此言学士修炼或真之由。 上清者，泥丸宫也。 华房者，三境华房也。 八冥者，八极也。 泥丸者，脑顶也。 绛宫者，心也。 五炁者，五行也。 百神者，身中之神也。 此盖修炼成真之验。 真中之神，灵妙已具，是以升降周流而不息，上则道於天门上清华房之问，周行八极之内，虽细微毫芒，亦无不至。 下则镇人身，复还本身之中，自泥丸下绛宫，而归中宫玄关也。 中者，一身之中也。 曰执中、守中、规中、环中、一中、黄中，皆一理也。 苟真息内定，中虚外明，而炁自调理矣。 五炁者，精神魂魄意也。 调息至於无息，则心净神凝，五炁内理，百神内合，周而复始，流行不息，周回至於十转，真中之神灵妙莫测； 身中之万炁，皆齐入仙道矣。
chunks.translated_text:
When the five qi pay homage to the origin, lead and mercury are captured and refined—thus seizing Heaven and Earth’s creative transformation, gathering within the crucible and furnace, traversing the twenty-eight lunar lodges, circulating the fire-timing of the celestial revolution. The medicine is gathered at the onset of the winter solstice, seizing the nodal qi of an entire year, at the very moment when the first yang stirs—this is the summation of qi’s upper origin. Thus it is said: the origin is the supreme of beginnings.

As one qi ascends to the mud-pill palace, the qi-timings of the eight nodes all merge in profound harmony. Thereby one enters directly into the midst of the mysterious mystery, where the indistinct and obscure contain essence. And when my primordial spirit and ancestral qi converge at the summit of the Great Abyss, this is the Highest Perfected’s rosy radiance above the three qi.

When the great rosy clouds stream forth their hues and the empty void forms sound, whistling and chanting arise in joyous resonance—this is the spontaneous response. The golden truths shine resplendent, their echoes flowing through the cloudy encampments. Jade tones gather qi, numinous winds amass mist. The Purple Void flourishes in elegance, aiding and sheltering the ten thousand immortals. A thousand harmonies, ten thousand unions—naturally they form the real.

Mo’an says: From this passage onward to "each has its gate of generation" constitutes the cavernous chapters of the Highest Perfected. The *golden truths* are the golden essence, the numinous root of Heaven and Earth, the ancestral qi of yin and yang, the primordial true unity’s essence, the utmost yang’s qi. The *jade tones* are the sounds of dragon’s chant and tiger’s roar. The *Purple Void* is the Central Yellow Palace.

Once the Golden Mother returns to the spirit-chamber and the cinnabar foundation is established, the golden embryo begins to sprout. The true spirit shines brilliantly, gleaming like the radiant clarity of golden essence. When the qi of the dragon and tiger’s two strings emerge—fire generating water—the jade tones flow in resonance, the numinous winds stir within, and qi returns to the spirit-chamber to nurture and form the *yin-e*. Within the Central Yellow earthen cauldron, purple light and crimson hues gather qi and amass mist, then flourish to congeal the real. Vigorous within and without, the ten thousand qi return to the real, like waters flowing to their source, like wheel-spokes converging at the hub—spirit flows freely, qi harmonizes.

A thousand spirits harmonize into one spirit, ten thousand qi merge into one qi—all is the principle of spontaneity. Internally conjoined to form the real, these are the most wondrous and divine mechanisms of the returned elixir, not achieved through artificial effort. As the scripture says: "When the revolving wind blends, the work is completed in a hundred days." The *Canticle* states: "Tending and nurturing the *yin-e*, congealing the spirit to form the body."

Within the real there is spirit—the Great Lord of Longevity, the Peerless Duke, the Venerable White Prime, the Great Unity Controller of Destiny, Peach-Kang and Union-Longevity—grasping talismans and holding registers, preserving life and engendering roots. That within the real there is spirit refers to the primordial spirit as the essence of nature, for it is indestructible from kalpas past—this is the Great Lord of Longevity. The "something within the indistinct" and the "essence within the obscure"—its essence is most real, and within it there is certainty.

The Peerless is the spirit of the liver; the White Prime, the spirit of the lungs; the Great Unity is the lord of the hundred spirits, the Controller of Destiny, the spirit of the heart; Peach-Kang and Union-Longevity are the spirits of the two kidneys. The Ancient Fool says: Speaking generally of the four spirits means that metal and wood do not obstruct each other, and water and fire do not overcome one another. The five spirits do not mention the spirit of the spleen, for without the central intent, the four images cannot harmonize—thus the spirit resides within it.

Therefore, the Great Unity dwells at the center, emblematizing the five phases. In the elixir way, Kan receives the earth of Wu, and Li receives the earth of Ji—this is called Kan’s Wu as the moon’s essence, Li’s Ji as the sun’s light. The union of water and fire, the fusion of lead and mercury, the merging of metal and wood—all are mediated by the central intent. The work of refinement, the most wondrous and divine mechanisms, do not exceed the principles of the five phases’ sequence and inversion.

If one can harmonize the sequential circumstances of daily life to investigate the marvels of inversion, the four images conjoin, the five phases gather—then the stem of life grows ever more secure, and the root of nature attains longevity. This is the utmost spirit within the utmost real. Guanfu says: The true spirit preserves its nature and life, the numinous qi guards its root of generation.

Talismans and registers—expressed in terms of form—are the primordial talismanic mandates. Sought within the formless, they are one’s own true qi. If one can grasp and uphold them without negligence, one may secure and strengthen the primordial life, so that the dead soul receives deliverance and revives its root.

Ascending to the Upper Clarity, entering and exiting the Flowery Chambers, within the eight obscurities and the subtlest realms. Below, it stabilizes the human body—mud-pill palace and crimson palace—governing the five qi within, blending the hundred spirits. Ten revolutions return the numinous, ten thousand qi unite as immortals.

Mo’an says: This describes how scholars refine and attain the real. The *Upper Clarity* is the mud-pill palace. The *Flowery Chambers* are the three realms’ flowery chambers. The *eight obscurities* are the eight poles. The *mud-pill* is the brain’s summit. The *crimson palace* is the heart. The *five qi* are the five phases. The *hundred spirits* are the spirits within the body. This is the verification of refining and attaining the real.

Within the real, the spirit’s numinous wonders are already complete—thus it ascends and descends, circulating without cease. Above, it courses through the Heavenly Gate and the Upper Clarity’s Flowery Chambers, circling within the eight poles—even in the subtlest and most minute, there is nowhere it does not reach. Below, it stabilizes the human body, returning to the body’s center from the mud-pill palace down to the crimson palace, and back to the mysterious pass of the central palace.

The *center*—the body’s center—is called grasping the center, guarding the center, compassing the center, encircling the center, the one center, the yellow center—all are one principle. If the true breath settles within and the center is empty while the exterior is bright, then qi naturally regulates itself. The *five qi* are essence, spirit, soul, spirit-soul, and intent. When breath is regulated to the point of no-breath, the heart is pure and the spirit congeals—the five qi govern within, the hundred spirits merge within, circulating and returning without cease. After ten revolutions, the spirit within the real is unfathomably numinous; the body’s ten thousand qi all enter the immortal way.

The *Grand August within the profound* is the Three Treasure Lords within the three qi of the Primordial Profundity—these are the Highest Perfected of the luminous rosy clouds, above the three qi of the Brahman clarity’s scene. The *cavernous chapters* are the golden truths’ radiant luxuriance, whistling and chanting the songs below. Cultivating within, the sun and moon unite as a jade bi—then water and fire achieve harmony.

chunks.original_text: 此乃内丹十月、功圆道备之应也。 所谓追二炁於黄道，会三性於元宫，摄情还性，归根复命之妙，尽於十转之功矣。 仙道贵生，无量度人。 上开八门，飞天法轮。 罪福禁戒，宿命因缘。 普受开度，死魂生身。 身得受生，上闻诸天。 诸天之上，各有生门。 默庵曰：此言世人罪福报应，而终可普受开度之恩也。 仙道长生之谓也。 故太上惟好生，初无限量之拘，是以普度无穷。 八门者，八方法轮之门。 人世罪福善恶，皆由心造，是有天堂地狱之分。 人之溺於贪叹之蔽，不知禁戒，或宿世今生，结习缠染而成，故有轮转之报。 今蒙天尊大慈，普受开度，上开八方之门，转动法轮，使灵光慧烛，如飞天之疾，下彻幽扃，则死魂受度，而生身矣。 既得受生，必假元始符命褊告诸天，然后诸天随其善功禀赋，受生生身，则有仙阶高下之品。 死魂则随果受生之门，而各受开度之恩也。 生门即生神所谓生门死户也。 诸天之上，各有所隶焉。 中有空洞，谣歌之章，魔王灵篇，辞参高真。 默庵曰：此魔王歌章之序，引元始褒取其篇以其参合高真洞章之辞。 空洞者，即前所谓天中空洞也。 谣歌者，魔王歌章也。 此三界魔王歌章之序，引元始以其辞语与洞章参合，故取以参之高真之中，是曰灵篇。 经法云：洞章者，乃龟山丹黄，飞玄紫文，非魔王所作也。 太上布此三章於世，令人开悟超出三界。 昔天尊降魔，魔王悉皆稽首受事，敕魔王统治三界，各歌谣章，变化飞空，警戒天人，屏绝欲鬼，令人闻此飞空之音，转色欲苦，归清净门。 上文曰：诸天之上，各有生门，继之曰中有空洞谣歌之章，则诸天之中，自有空洞之章也。 其魔王所作，飞空歌音，义在敬戒，理契天真，是足以参於高真也。 第一欲界飞空之音： 默庵曰：欲界者，天人之际，在人身即心肾界也。 超鬼道则为人，入仙道则飞空。 古愚曰：魔王讳郁默。 道经云：凡人口业净，有十善功以上，生欲界六天。 《灵宝经法》云：自黄曾至摩夷，为欲界； 六欲俱净，则升色界。 人道眇眇，仙道莽莽； 鬼道乐兮，当人生门。 天道贵生，鬼道贵终。 仙道常自吉，鬼道常自凶。 高上清灵爽，悲歌朗太空。 惟愿仙道成，不欲人道穷。 北都泉曲府，中有万鬼群。 但欲遏人算，断绝人命门。 阿人歌洞章，以摄北罗酆。 束送妖魔精，斩馘六鬼锋。 诸天炁荡荡，我道日兴隆。 默庵曰：此言吾身之北都泉曲府，即北都罗酆也。 万鬼群，即妖魔精六鬼锋也。 我能摄伏之、束送之、斩馘之，则天炁日长於我，而仙道日成於我矣。 眇眇者，轻眇也。 莽莽者，高远也。 生门者，生死关也。 灵爽者，鬼趣也。 泉曲府，身中之北阴也。 命门，即命蒂也。 人道眇邈，微而难尽，仙道高远幽而难明。 是以人自有形，即贪着染缚，目之於色，耳之於声，鼻之於臭，口之於味，皆三毒六欲之根，是有三途、五苦之报也。 以人不能修仙道，故鬼道快乐，当人生死之门，务欲人之死绝也。 故天道好生，而鬼则贵终矣。 然则趋于仙道者，务欲崇德积善，其自召者，靡不吉。 沦於鬼道者，务欲贼德害善，其自求者，靡不凶矣。 高上清灵爽，魔王言其所居之高广，非灵爽所能侵也。 朗然悲歌，飞游太空，盖悯人之去仙道远也。
chunks.translated_text:
This marks the response of the ten-month internal elixir, when merit is complete and the Dao perfected. Here lies the subtlety of pursuing the two qi along the Yellow Way, uniting the three natures in the primordial palace, drawing emotions back to nature, and returning to the root to restore life—all accomplished through the ten revolutions of practice.

The immortal way values life and delivers boundless beings. Above, the eight gates open, and the celestial Dharma-wheel takes flight. Karmic retribution, prohibitions, past-life causes, and conditions—all receive universal deliverance, where dead souls gain living bodies. Once the body attains rebirth, it ascends to be heard by the various heavens. Above the heavens, each has its own gate of life.

Mo’an says: This speaks of the karmic retribution of worldly beings, yet all may ultimately receive the grace of deliverance. Such is the immortal way of long life. Thus, the Most High cherishes life without limit, universally delivering the infinite. The eight gates are the portals of the eight-directional Dharma-wheel. The good and evil of worldly karma are all created by the mind, giving rise to the division of heaven and hell. People, drowned in the obscuration of greed and lament, unaware of prohibitions, or bound by past-life and present habits, become entangled and stained—hence the retribution of cyclic rebirth. Now, by the great compassion of the Heavenly Worthy, all receive deliverance: above, the eight directional gates open, the Dharma-wheel turns, and the radiance of wisdom shines swiftly like flying celestials, penetrating the darkest depths. Thus, dead souls are delivered and gain living bodies. Having received rebirth, one must rely on the talismanic decree of the Primordial Beginning to petition the heavens, whereupon the heavens, according to one’s merit and endowment, grant a living body—resulting in ranks of immortals, high and low. Dead souls, following the gate of karmic rebirth, each receive the grace of deliverance.

The gate of life refers to the "gate of life and door of death" spoken of in the *Scripture of Life Spirits*. Above the heavens, each has its own jurisdiction. Within them lies the empty cavern, the verses of chanting songs, the numinous chapters of demon kings, and the words that match the exalted perfected. Mo’an says: This is the preface to the demon kings’ songs, where the Primordial Beginning selects their verses to harmonize with the cavernous chapters of the exalted perfected. The "empty cavern" refers to the "empty cavern within heaven" mentioned earlier. The "chanting songs" are the demon kings’ verses. This preface to the demon kings’ songs of the three realms cites the Primordial Beginning’s words to match the cavernous chapters, hence incorporating them among the exalted perfected—this is called the *Numinous Chapter*.

The scriptures and methods state: The cavernous chapters are the cinnabar and yellow of Mount Gui, the soaring mysterious purple script—not composed by demon kings. The Most High disseminated these three chapters to the world, enabling people to awaken and transcend the three realms. When the Heavenly Worthy descended to subdue the demons, the demon kings all bowed their heads in submission, and were commanded to govern the three realms, each singing verses that transform and fly through the void, warning celestial and human beings, repelling desire-demons, so that those who hear this flying celestial sound turn from the suffering of sensual desire and return to the gate of purity.

The preceding text states: "Above the heavens, each has its own gate of life," and continues, "within them lies the empty cavern and verses of chanting songs"—thus, within the heavens, there are naturally cavernous chapters. The demon kings’ flying celestial songs, in their meaning of reverence and warning, resonate with the celestial perfected, and are thus worthy to be matched with the exalted perfected.

The first is the flying celestial sound of the Desire Realm:

Mo’an says: The Desire Realm lies at the boundary between celestials and humans; in the human body, it is the realm of heart and kidneys. Transcending the ghost path leads to humanity; entering the immortal way leads to flying through the void. Gu Yu says: The demon king’s name is Yu Mo. The Daoist scriptures state: If one’s oral karma is pure, possessing ten good deeds or more, one is born in the six heavens of the Desire Realm. The *Lingbao Scriptures and Methods* state: From Huangzeng to Moye is the Desire Realm; when the six desires are all purified, one ascends to the Form Realm.

The human path is faint and distant, the immortal way vast and remote;
The ghost path delights in endings, while the human gate is life.
The celestial way values life, the ghost way values death.
The immortal way is ever auspicious, the ghost way ever inauspicious.
Exalted, pure, and numinous, I chant sorrowfully in the great void.
I only wish the immortal way to succeed, not the human path to perish.
The Northern Capital’s Spring Bend Prefecture holds a myriad ghostly hosts,
All seeking to cut short human lifespans and sever the gate of life.
Ah! Sing the cavernous chapters to restrain the Northern Feng,
Bind and dispatch the demonic essences, behead the six ghostly blades.
The qi of the various heavens surges boundlessly, my Dao daily flourishes.

Mo’an says: This speaks of the Northern Capital’s Spring Bend Prefecture within our bodies—namely, the Northern Feng. The myriad ghostly hosts are the demonic essences and six ghostly blades. If I can restrain, bind, dispatch, and behead them, then the celestial qi daily grows within me, and the immortal way daily manifests within me.

"Faint and distant" means subtle and elusive. "Vast and remote" means lofty and far-reaching. The "gate of life" is the threshold of life and death. "Numinous spirits" refers to the ghostly realm. The Spring Bend Prefecture is the northern yin within the body. The "gate of life" is the stem of life. The human path is faint and fleeting, subtle and hard to exhaust; the immortal way is lofty, remote, and hard to fathom. Thus, from the moment humans take form, they become attached and bound—eyes to forms, ears to sounds, nose to scents, mouth to tastes—all roots of the three poisons and six desires, leading to the retribution of the three paths and five sufferings. Because people cannot cultivate the immortal way, the ghost path seems joyful, standing at the gate of human life and death, seeking only human annihilation. Thus, the celestial way cherishes life, while ghosts value death.

Yet those who pursue the immortal way must cultivate virtue and accumulate goodness, and whatever they summon will be auspicious. Those who sink into the ghost path must harm virtue and goodness, and whatever they seek will be inauspicious. "Exalted, pure, and numinous"—the demon king speaks of his dwelling’s vastness, which no numinous spirit can invade. Chanting sorrowfully, flying through the great void, he pities those who drift far from the immortal way.

chunks.original_text: 惟愿学者仙道之成，不欲人道之穷极也。 北都泉曲府，即北都罗酆也。 冥关岱岳所治，职掌罪罚，校录愆过，三界四司、岳渎隍社，凡遇三元八节、五腊三会，考校功过，毫发无私。 若能持善修福，则延寿长年； 为恶致祸，则灭算除年，录送酆都泉曲矣。 其罗酆之府，有万鬼群，本欲遏绝人之寿算，以断人之命根，不欲仙道之成也。 北都罗酆在人身，即爱河欲海也。 不能窒欲养心，则妄念纷飞，皆为妖魔精矣。 阿人歌咏空洞之章，以摄制罗酆之鬼，趣束送之、斩馘之，使妖魔六鬼之锋刃，顿尔泯息。 内功外行既积，万善日备，则诸天之正熙荡荡，我道由此而兴隆矣。 第二色界魔王之章： 默庵曰：色界者，中天之天，在人即心目界也。 无染着，则能变化飞升矣。 少微曰：魔王讳摩罗。 道经云：身业净有三百善功，生色界。 自越行天至昙誓天，共一十八天，为色界。 此天之人有形无欲，分麓细轻，一十八尘，尘染俱净，升无色界。 落落高张，明炁四骞。 梵行诸天，周回十方。 无量大神，皆由我身。 我有洞章，万徧成仙。 仙道贵度，鬼道相连。 天地眇莽，秽气氛氛。 三界乐兮，过之长存。 身度我界，体入自然。 此时乐兮，薄由我恩。 龙汉荡荡，何能别真。 我界难度，故作洞文。 变化飞空，以试尔身。 成败懈退，度者几人。 笑尔不度，故为歌音。 落落者，天体之廓落也。 明炁者，梵炁明洁，四方周布，流行於诸天十方，周匝俱徧矣。 无量大神，魔王言其变化无量，皆其身中之神也。 洞章即前所谓乃龟山丹黄，飞玄紫文，具载灵宝法中，非魔王歌也。 万徧者，必真积力久，然后力到功圆而成仙矣。 非惟诵之多也。 仙道所贵者，长生度世也。 鬼道所牵连者，人不能自修，身殁炁散，魂神被考，累贻祖玄矣。 天地之广大，眇莽难穷，而秽浊之气纷纭交结於其中。 三界之内，惟过度者可以长存，而获至乐。 我界，乃魔王自谓也。 能过度此界，则体合自然，结习俱忘，升入无形矣。 至此，则六根俱净，八识俱空，湛然一真，其乐无际，虽由功满德就而然，亦自魔王保举而仙。 故曰薄由我恩也。 龙汉者，元始初劫之名，荡荡广汉无际也。 当祖劫之初，大朴未散，浑然本性之真，岂有精粗纯杂之别。 自人欲既萌，情识交蔽，则本然之性遂有区别，业识流转无已，至乃我界难度矣。 是作此洞文，以训励之，欲人证道成真，以度此界也。 洞文即歌章也。 变化飞空，魔王言其神化无方，以试学道之心； 或试以所欲，或试以所畏，或试以所不欲不畏； 日久月深，心如铁石，终无退怠，则道功成矣。 然而成败懈退，不为魔所沮弃，而竟度三界者，复几人哉！ 或中道而废，致贻魔王之笑，其不度也。 设为歌音，良有所勉迪焉。 此其修炼之士，必平素积功累行，有以通于神明，则内魔不生，外魔自息，道功乃就，而可度世矣。 第三无色界魔王歌曰： 默庵曰：无色界在天为天顶，在人则为泥丸顶也。 少微曰：魔王讳韶，道经云：心业净，有六百善行，生无色界四天。 自皓庭天至秀乐四天，为无色界。 《本际经》曰：烦恼为结，学业为习，结习已尽，超种民位。 洞入道境，随炁升降，灾所不及也。 三界之上，眇眇大罗。

May scholars only aspire to the fulfillment of the immortal Dao, not the exhaustion of the human way. The Northern Metropolis’ Springs and Bends Prefecture is none other than the Northern Metropolis of Fengdu. The Dark Pass is governed by Mount Tai, where the office oversees the meting of punishments, the tallying of transgressions, and the recording of faults. The Three Realms’ Four Bureaus—mountains, rivers, moats, and altars—on the Three Origins, Eight Festivals, Five La Days, and Three Assemblies, examine and assess merits and demerits with impartiality, down to the finest detail. Those who uphold goodness and cultivate blessings extend their years and lengthen their lives; those who do evil and incur misfortune have their allotted years erased and their lifespans cut short, their records sent to Fengdu’s Springs and Bends. Within Fengdu’s precincts, a multitude of ghosts conspire to intercept and sever human lifespans, cutting off the root of life, unwilling to see the immortal Dao fulfilled.

The Northern Metropolis of Fengdu within the human body is the River of Love and Sea of Desire. If one cannot restrain desire and nurture the heart-mind, then deluded thoughts scatter like flying dust, all becoming demonic spirits. Ah, let one chant the empty and cavernous verses to subdue and restrain Fengdu’s ghosts, driving them to be bound, sent away, and beheaded, so that the blades of the six demonic ghosts may instantly vanish and fall silent. With inner cultivation and outer conduct accumulated, and myriad virtues perfected day by day, the celestial way’s true radiance will flourish boundlessly, and our Dao shall thus prosper.

**Second: The Chapter of the Form Realm’s Demon King**

Mo’an says: The Form Realm is the heaven of the middle heavens; within humans, it is the realm of the heart-mind and eyes. Free from attachment, one can transform, take flight, and ascend. Shaowei says: The Demon King’s name is Mara. The Daoist scriptures state: With three hundred virtuous deeds in bodily conduct, one is born into the Form Realm. From Yuexing Heaven to Tanshi Heaven, there are eighteen heavens in all, comprising the Form Realm. The people of this heaven possess form but no desire; their allotments are subtle and light, the eighteen dusts, and the dusts’ defilements are all purified, ascending to the Formless Realm.

Lofty and vast, luminous qi spreads in all four directions. The Brahma-conduct heavens encircle the ten directions. Boundless great spirits all arise from within my body. I possess cavernous verses—ten thousand recitations, and one becomes immortal. The immortal Dao values deliverance; the ghost path clings fast. Heaven and earth stretch boundless, foul qi swirling thickly. Within the Three Realms, joy endures—pass beyond it, and it abides long. Crossing my realm, the body enters spontaneity. At this time, joy is but a trifling grace of mine. The Dragon Han is vast—how can one distinguish the true? My realm is hard to cross, so I compose these cavernous texts. Transforming and flying through the void, I test your body. Success or failure, slackening or retreat—how many will cross? I laugh at those who do not cross, so I sing these songs.

“Lofty” describes the vastness of the celestial body. “Luminous qi” refers to the bright and pure Brahma-qi, spreading in all four directions, flowing through the heavens of the ten directions, pervading all. The “boundless great spirits” are the Demon King’s words on his limitless transformations, all the spirits within his body. The “cavernous verses” are the aforementioned cinnabar-yellow texts of Mount Gui, the soaring mysterious purple script, fully recorded in the *Lingbao* methods—this is not the Demon King’s song. “Ten thousand recitations” means that only after long and sincere accumulation of power will effort reach fruition and immortality be achieved—not merely through frequent recitation.

What the immortal Dao values is long life and deliverance from the world. What the ghost path entangles is this: when people cannot cultivate themselves, their bodies perish and their qi disperses; their hun and shen are examined, and their ancestors and forebears are implicated. Heaven and earth are vast and boundless, yet foul and turbid qi swirls and intertwines within them. Within the Three Realms, only those who transcend can abide long and attain supreme joy. “My realm” is the Demon King’s self-reference. Those who cross this realm merge their bodies with spontaneity, all habitual tendencies forgotten, ascending into the formless. At this stage, the six senses are all purified, the eight consciousnesses all empty, utterly serene and unified in truth—its joy is boundless. Though this arises from the fulfillment of power and virtue, it is also through the Demon King’s sponsorship that one becomes immortal. Thus it is said: “a trifling grace of mine.”

The Dragon Han is the name of the Primordial Beginning’s first kalpa, vast and boundless. At the dawn of the ancestral kalpa, the great simplicity had not yet dispersed, and the true nature of original being was undifferentiated—how could there be distinctions of purity and impurity, refinement and coarseness? Once human desire arose and emotions and perceptions obscured it, the original nature became divided, and karmic consciousness flowed endlessly, until even my realm became hard to cross. Thus I compose these cavernous texts to instruct and encourage, desiring that people realize the Dao and attain truth, crossing this realm.

The “cavernous texts” are the song-verses. “Transforming and flying through the void,” the Demon King speaks of his unfathomable spiritual transformations, testing the hearts of Dao cultivators: sometimes with what they desire, sometimes with what they fear, sometimes with what they neither desire nor fear. Over days and months, if the heart becomes like iron and stone, unwavering and without slackening, then the Dao’s work is accomplished. Yet how many, despite success or failure, slackening or retreat, are not deterred by demons and ultimately cross the Three Realms? Some falter midway, incurring the Demon King’s laughter—they do not cross. The songs are composed with good intent to encourage. Those who cultivate must accumulate merit and conduct over time, connecting with the numinous. Then inner demons do not arise, outer demons naturally cease, the Dao’s work is accomplished, and one can be delivered from the world.

**Third: The Song of the Formless Realm’s Demon King**

Mo’an says: The Formless Realm in heaven is the celestial summit; within humans, it is the Niwan summit. Shaowei says: The Demon King’s name is Shao. The Daoist scriptures state: With six hundred virtuous deeds in the heart-mind, one is born into the Formless Realm’s four heavens. From Haoting Heaven to Xiule’s four heavens, these comprise the Formless Realm. The *Benji Jing* says: Afflictions are knots; learning and conduct are habits. When knots and habits are exhausted, one transcends the rank of the seed people.

Entering the cavernous Dao’s境, one ascends and descends with the qi, untouched by calamity. Above the Three Realms, the vast and distant Great Luo.

chunks.original_text: 上无色根，云层峨峨。 唯有元始，浩劫之家。 部制我界，统承玄都。 有过我界，身入玉虚。 我位上王，匡御众魔。 空中万变，秽气纷葩。 保真者少，迷惑者多。 仙道难固，鬼道易邪。 人道者心，谅不由他。 仙道贵实，人道贵华。 尔不乐仙道，三界那得过。 其欲转五道，我当复奈何。 默庵曰：眇眇大罗，指三十二天之顶也。 天以北极部制诸天，上无色根，指三百六十骨节之顶也。 人以百会部制一身。 观复曰：三界之上，即种民四天之上，即大罗天也。 大罗天上有玉京山，层云所覆。 元始天尊自浩劫以来，宅居其中，部制三界，统治玄都大罗玉清之境。 我界，即无色界也。 玉虚，乃虚无玉京也。 修炼之士，得度无色界，入四种民天，则身入玉虚之境矣。 我位上王，魔王自谓其功品居诸魔王之上，是以众魔皆由其匡御也。 下视虚空之中，色尘业垢，起灭万变，秽浊之气纷葩交绕，是以能保固本真者甚少，而迷惑昏妄者愈多。 仙道则不得坚固，而惟入于鬼道之邪妄矣。 人道者，心收之则万殊一本，放之则一本万殊。 物物各具一太极，莫非此心也。 人心、道心、存心、养心、正心、修心、观心、澄心、照心，三教同一心法也。 岂有它哉！ 仙道贵实者，诚实无妄也。 人道则乐於华竞矣。 苟不好乐仙道，思自修之，岂能过三界之上也。 故必转五道之苦轮，我亦将如之奈何。 此盖魔王训励之切也。 五道者，神、人、禽兽、饿鬼、地狱也。 此三界之上，飞空之中，魔王歌音，音参洞章。 诵之百徧，名度南宫。 诵之千褊，魔王保迎。 万徧道备，飞升太空，过度三界，位登仙公。 此总赞前歌章也。 魔王在三界之上，飞行太空之中，作为歌音，可参合洞章之微妙，使学者日进於道。 自欲界而色界，至无色界，诵咏其音，至百而千而万徧，莫非恐人有懈退之心，而欲其念念归真也。 此所以身道之难成，非志坚行笃所不能至也。 又至万徧而后，道备乃可飞升太空，遇度三界之上，而位证仙公矣。 仙公者，太极仙品之至高也。 况万徧非徒口诵也，必内功外行，深积厚培之力，而后方能上升太空，位登仙品也。 故天尊取以续於正经，赞之曰：灵篇灵音，其所感召，可谓至重矣。 是以其辞参高真，音参洞章也。 有闻灵音，魔王敬形。 敕制地祇，侍卫送迎。 拔出地户，五苦八难，七祖升迁，永离鬼官。 魂度朱陵，受炼更生。 是谓无量，普度无穷，有秘上天文，诸天共所崇。 泄慢堕地狱，祸及七祖翁。 默庵曰：此言魔章普度之功，学士泄慢之报。 元始说经之言止此。 灵音，赞重魔王之歌音也。 有能闻是音而修之不怠者，魔王敬奉其形神矣。 故观复曰：闻非耳闻也，必心与经通，行与经合是也。 念念不忘，常存敬惧，外遣诸缘，内修定力。 久之功深行满，上帝勃命地只祀典之神，侍卫其居处，送迎其出入，虽道未备，不能度三界，位仙公，亦必拔出地户，离死户也。 无复五苦八难之厄矣。 其功则上及七祖，皆获升迁，永离幽关，不属鬼官之所考摄。 魂神径度朱陵火府，而更生乐界矣。 是以生死皆蒙其无量之功，无穷之度矣。 内功至此，圣胎已就，脱体神化，阴尽阳纯，直超三界之上，七祖同升矣。 虽然经功之效昭着，若此秘於诸天之上，共所尊崇，苟有泄慢之愆，不惟身堕地狱，则必祸延七祖，可不戒之慎之。

Above the rootless Formless, cloud-layers rise in towering peaks.
Only the Primordial Beginning dwells in the home of vast kalpas.
It governs and orders our realm, receiving its mandate from Mysterious Capital.
Whoever transgresses our realm enters the Jade Void.
My station is the supreme king, rectifying and ruling all demons.
In the emptiness, ten thousand transformations arise; impure qi blooms in profusion.
Those who preserve the true are few; those who stray and delude are many.
The immortal Dao is hard to secure; the ghostly path easily turns to deviance.
The human path lies in the heart-mind—truly, it does not depend on others.
The immortal Dao values substance; the human path values splendor.
If you do not delight in the immortal Dao, how can you pass beyond the Three Realms?
Should you wish to revolve through the Five Paths, what then can I do for you?

Mo’an says: The vast and distant Great Luo refers to the summit of the thirty-two heavens. Heaven is governed by the Northern Culmen, which orders all heavens. The rootless Formless refers to the summit of the three hundred sixty bones and joints. In humans, the Hundred Meetings governs the entire body. Guanfu says: Above the Three Realms lies the Four Heavens of the Seed People, which is the Great Luo Heaven. Above the Great Luo Heaven stands the Jade Capital Mountain, veiled by layered clouds. Since the beginning of vast kalpas, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy has dwelt within, governing the Three Realms and ruling the Mysterious Capital’s Great Luo Jade Clarity. Our realm is the Formless Realm. The Jade Void is the Void’s Jade Capital. Those who cultivate and refine, attaining deliverance from the Formless Realm and entering the Four Heavens of the Seed People, then enter the realm of the Jade Void. My station is the supreme king—the Demon King declares his merit and rank stand above all other demon kings, thus all demons are rectified and ruled by him. Gazing down upon the emptiness, the dusts of form and the filth of karma arise and vanish in ten thousand transformations; impure and turbid qi intertwine in profusion. Thus, those who can preserve and secure their original true nature are few, while those who become deluded and confused are many. The immortal Dao cannot be firmly established, and one easily falls into the deviance of the ghostly path. The human path: when the heart-mind gathers it, the ten thousand differences return to one root; when it scatters, one root becomes ten thousand differences. Each thing possesses its own Supreme Ultimate—none but this heart-mind. The human heart, the Dao-heart, preserving the heart, nurturing the heart, rectifying the heart, cultivating the heart, observing the heart, settling the heart, illuminating the heart—all Three Teachings share this single heart-method. How could there be another? The immortal Dao values substance: sincerity without falsehood. The human path delights in competitive splendor. If one does not delight in the immortal Dao and aspire to self-cultivation, how can one pass beyond the Three Realms? Thus, one must revolve through the suffering wheel of the Five Paths—what then can I do? This is the Demon King’s earnest admonition. The Five Paths are: gods, humans, birds and beasts, hungry ghosts, and hells.

This realm above the Three Realms, in the flying emptiness, is where the Demon King’s song resounds, its tones interwoven with cavernous chapters. Reciting it a hundred times delivers one to the Southern Palace. Reciting it a thousand times, the Demon King protects and welcomes. After ten thousand recitations, the Dao is complete—one soars into the great emptiness, passes beyond the Three Realms, and ascends to the rank of Immortal Duke. This is the general praise for the preceding song.

The Demon King, in the realm above the Three Realms, flies through the great emptiness, composing his song. It can be interwoven with the subtle wonders of cavernous chapters, guiding cultivators to daily progress on the Way. From the Realm of Desire through the Realm of Form to the Formless Realm, reciting and chanting its tones—first a hundred, then a thousand, then ten thousand times—there is no fear of slackening or retreat, only the aspiration that each thought returns to the true. Thus, the difficulty of attaining the embodied Dao can only be overcome by those with resolute will and steadfast conduct. Only after ten thousand recitations, when the Dao is complete, can one soar into the great emptiness, pass beyond the Three Realms, and attain the rank of Immortal Duke. The Immortal Duke is the highest rank of the Supreme Ultimate’s immortal grades. Moreover, ten thousand recitations are not merely oral recitation—they require the power of deep accumulation and thick cultivation through inner work and outer conduct, only then can one ascend into the great emptiness and attain the immortal ranks. Thus, the Heavenly Worthy included it in the orthodox scriptures, praising it: "This numinous chapter and numinous tone—its power of summoning is truly of the utmost weight." Therefore, its words interweave with those of the lofty perfected, its tones with cavernous chapters.

Those who hear the numinous tone, the Demon King respects their form. He commands earth spirits to attend and protect, escorting them in departure and return. They are plucked from the earthly gate, freed from the five sufferings and eight hardships. Seven generations of ancestors ascend and migrate, forever departing the ghostly officials. The soul crosses the Vermilion Mound, undergoes refinement, and is reborn. This is called boundless deliverance, universally liberating without end. There are secret celestial texts, revered by all heavens. Those who leak and slight them fall into hell, bringing calamity upon seven generations of ancestors.

Mo’an says: This speaks of the universal deliverance of the demonic chapters and the retribution for scholars who leak and slight. The Primordial Beginning’s scriptural teachings end here. The "numinous tone" praises the weight of the Demon King’s song. Those who hear this tone and cultivate without negligence—the Demon King reveres their form and spirit. Thus, Guanfu says: Hearing is not merely ear-hearing; it requires the heart to commune with the scripture and conduct to align with the scripture. Thoughts must never be forgotten, always maintaining reverence and awe. Externally, one dispels all conditions; internally, one cultivates the power of concentration. Over time, with deep merit and complete conduct, the Celestial Thearch commands the spirits of earthly sacrifices to attend and protect one’s dwelling, escorting departures and returns. Even if the Dao is not yet complete and one cannot pass beyond the Three Realms or attain the rank of Immortal Duke, one is still plucked from the earthly gate, freed from the gate of death. No longer subject to the hardships of the five sufferings and eight difficulties, one’s merit extends upward to seven generations of ancestors, all ascending and migrating, forever departing the dark passes and no longer subject to the governance of ghostly officials. The soul directly crosses the Vermilion Mound’s Fire Bureau and is reborn in the realm of bliss. Thus, both life and death receive its boundless merit and endless deliverance. At this stage of inner work, the sacred embryo is complete—one sheds the body, spirit transforms, yin is exhausted, and yang is pure. One directly transcends above the Three Realms, and seven generations of ancestors ascend together.

Although the effects of scriptural merit are thus manifest, if this secret is revered by all heavens above, those who commit the transgression of leaking and slighting will not only fall into hell themselves but will also bring calamity upon seven generations of ancestors. One cannot but be warned and cautious.

chunks.original_text: 道言：此二章并是诸天上帝，及至灵魔王隐秘之音，皆是大梵之言，非世上常辞。 言无韵丽，曲无华宛，故谓玄奥，难可寻详。 上天所宝，秘於玄都紫微上宫，依玄科，四万劫一传。 若有至人赍金宝质心，依旧格告盟十天，然后而付焉。 默庵曰：自此至洞明至言五段，是道君再序经文玄妙之功用，乃正经之后序也。 此二章灵宝后序，指言此二章者，即前上一章元始洞玄灵宝本章，及下一章中有空洞谣歌之章也。 上天所宝，此道君再序经文玄妙，上天宝爱之意。 观复曰：此二章混洞赤文、元洞玉历是也。 一明先天之道，一明后天之道。 混洞赤文章，言天帝名讳，五天号讳，其文主於超技玄祖，受度生身，敷落普度，历关告命之旨。 元洞玉历章，言劫运成败，混沌开辟，元炁周流，探取修炼，归根复命，超凡入圣之道。 故曰皆隐秘之音、大梵之言，非世之常辞所能至也。 言无韵丽，谓天尊经旨之洁净精微也。 曲无华宛，谓魔王歌章之明白简直也。 然其义玄奥幽微，学者不能尽究其详密，若夫默庵祖师之谓，自灵宝本章至谣歌之章，为二章者，其文义亦同而赤文玉历在其中矣。 皆隐秘大梵之言，故上天之宝於玄都紫微之宫，必依玄科禁戒，经累劫而后传。 又岂敢轻泄妄受也哉。 至士之欲受经者，必赍金质心，依天真条格告盟天真上圣而后付受，其可轻忽妄授，视为常辞也乎。 此皆道君谆笃之至训也。 道言：夫天地运度，亦有否终； 日月五星，亦有亏盈； 至圣神人，亦有休否； 末学之夫，亦有疾伤。

chunks.original_text: 凡有此灾，同气皆当齐心修斋，六时行香，十徧转经，福德立降，消诸不祥。 无量之文，普度无穷。 天地为万物之根本，毕竟囿於形气，运数亦有否泰，故遇阳九百六之厄，三界消亡，坏而后复成。 日月五星之衡度，亦有薄蚀盈缩，至圣神人亦有通塞休否，而况末学之夫，宁无疾伤？ 故凡有疾厄之苦，必当甘受忽怨，以顺其天也。 然人与天地万物均一炁也。 是曰一本万殊也。 先儒以乾为父，坤为母，民吾同胞，物吾一体者，此也。 故凡有是灾，同气皆当齐心修斋，六时行香，十徧转经，虽上消天灾，下度兆民，捍厄扶衰，无所祷而不应，是致福德立降，消诸不祥，皆十徧经之效也。 可谓无量之文，普度天人於无穷矣。 道言：夫末学道浅，或仙品未充，运应灭度，身经太阴。 临过之时，同学至人，为其行香诵经十过，以度尸形。 如法魂神径上南宫，随其学功，计日而得更生。 转轮不灭，便得神仙。 此专为末学道浅者言，以其道浅，是以仙品未充，运当灭度之际，身修仙道未备，体未纯阳，必经太阴之所考掠。 太阴犹北阴泉曲也。 临过之时，遇其将过尽之时。 同学至人，为其行香诵经十过。 同学者，或同师同道，所学已至之人，当为行香诵经，一遵十回之式，以度尸形。 如法，假其已炼之真阳，修诵是经，以度其尸形之至阴，送其魂神上生南宫。 尸者，魄之未化。 形者，气之未化。 必资经功道力，炼质陶魂，庶可径上南宫也。 随其学功，计日而得更生，各随其学业之浅深，功德之高下，而后计日之期限，随品受生，转轮不能灭其本性。 一灵不昧，久之，玄功积习之至，亦得仙道矣。 道言：夫天地运终，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 星宿错度，日月失昏，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 四时失度，阴阳不调，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 国主有灾，兵革四兴，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 疫毒流行，兆民死伤，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 师友命过，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 夫斋戒诵经，功德甚重。 上消天灾，保镇帝王，下禳毒害，以度兆民。 生死受赖，其福难胜。 故曰无量，普度天人。 青元曰：道君此章，明此经非惟度己，虽天地、君臣、民物，皆当兼济，方为道备，乃显度人之普也。 夫天地运终，以皇极元会运世论之，天地亦有成坏始终，皆不能逃乎运数。 《易》曰：天地毁，无以见易是也。 人身与造化同徒，故可以参天地、赞化育、裁成其道，辅相其宜也。 先儒不曰天人一政之功，以其心与理一而已。 夫以主宰谓之帝，妙用谓之鬼神，岂非一致哉！ 故当运有否终，亦必修斋诵经以禳之。 星宿错度谓躔度乖错，晷刻讹谬。 日月失昏，谓盈亏薄蚀，此亦囿於迟留伏逆之数也。 亦必修斋诵经以禳之。 四时失度，谓寒暑不常； 阴阳不调，谓旱潦为虐。 皆愆於天地之至和而然也亦爻修斋诵经以禳之。 国主有灾，兵革四兴，凡灾异兵革，莫非阴阳悖逆、政化乘违而致，其修德政、省刑罚、抚黎庶、治师旅、任贤能、安社稷，皆所以消天变而息人殃也。 此圣君贤臣之所首务，然苟有是灾，亦当修斋诵经以禳检之。 盖以请命於天，而天必弭灾以降祥也。 疫毒流行，兆民死伤。 疫毒者，疫疠之炁，流毒於兆民，必见死伤。 亦当修齐诵经，以禳释之，使其炁候正，则疫炁息矣。

Whenever such calamities arise, those of shared qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times through. Thereupon, virtue and power descend at once, dissolving all inauspiciousness. These boundless texts universally deliver limitless beings.

Heaven and earth are the root of the myriad things, yet ultimately confined by form and qi; their revolutions, too, have their adversities and prosperities. Thus, when encountering the tribulations of the Nine Yangs and Hundred Sixes, the Three Realms perish, only to be reconstituted thereafter. The celestial courses of the sun, moon, and five planets, too, have their eclipses and fluctuations; even the utmost sagely and divine beings have their passages and blockages, flourishings and declines—how much more the lesser learners, could they be free of illness and affliction? Therefore, when suffering the bitterness of illness and adversity, one must willingly accept and not complain, thereby aligning with Heaven.

Yet humans, heaven and earth, and the myriad things are all of a single qi—this is called "one root, ten thousand differences." The former scholars spoke of Qian as father and Kun as mother, of the people as our siblings and things as our single body—this is what they meant. Thus, whenever such calamities arise, those of shared qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times through. Whether to dissolve celestial disasters above or deliver the multitudes below, to ward off adversity and sustain the declining, there is no prayer that goes unanswered. Thus, virtue and power descend at once, dissolving all inauspiciousness—all through the efficacy of the tenfold recitation. Truly, these are boundless texts that universally deliver heaven and humanity without end.

The Dao speaks: The lesser learners, their Dao shallow and immortal rank unfulfilled, when their destined time of extinction arrives, their bodies pass through the Great Yin. At the hour of their passing, fellow learners and perfected ones perform incense offerings and recite the scripture ten times to deliver their corporeal forms. By this method, the hun-souls ascend directly to the Southern Palace, where, according to their accumulated merit, they are reborn after a reckoning of days. Their wheel of rebirth unbroken, they thereby attain divine transcendence.

This is spoken especially for the lesser learners of shallow Dao, whose immortal rank remains unfulfilled. When their destined time of extinction arrives, their cultivation of the immortal Dao incomplete and their bodies not yet purely yang, they must pass through the trials of the Great Yin. The Great Yin is akin to the Northern Yin Springs’ winding depths. At the hour of their passing—when their allotted time nears its end—fellow learners and perfected ones, those of the same teacher or Dao who have attained realization, must perform incense offerings and recite the scripture ten times through to deliver their corporeal forms. By this method, they borrow the perfected ones’ refined yang to recite the scripture, thereby delivering the extreme yin of the corpse and sending the hun-souls to ascend and be reborn in the Southern Palace. The *shi* (corpse) is the untransformed *po*; the *xing* (form) is the untransformed qi. Only through the merit of the scripture and the power of the Dao, refining the substance and molding the hun, can they ascend directly to the Southern Palace. According to their accumulated merit, they are reborn after a reckoning of days, each receiving rebirth in accordance with their learning’s depth and their virtue’s height. Their wheel of rebirth unable to extinguish their fundamental nature, their single spirit undimmed, over time, through the accumulation of profound practice, they, too, attain the immortal Dao.

The Dao speaks: When the revolutions of heaven and earth reach their end, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When the stellar lodges deviate from their courses and the sun and moon lose their proper times, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When the sovereign faces calamity and warfare arises on all sides, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When pestilential toxins spread and the multitudes perish, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture. When teachers and friends pass away, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture.

Purification rites and scripture recitation carry immense merit. Above, they dissolve celestial disasters and secure the emperor’s reign; below, they dispel toxins and deliver the multitudes. In life and death, all rely upon them—such blessings are beyond measure. Thus, they are called boundless, universally delivering heaven and humanity.

Qingyuan said: In this chapter, the Dao Lord clarifies that this scripture not only delivers oneself but also universally aids heaven and earth, sovereigns and ministers, the people and all things—only then is the Dao complete, manifesting the universal deliverance of beings. When the revolutions of heaven and earth reach their end, according to the Supreme Ultimate’s Yuan-Hui-Yun-Shi reckoning, even heaven and earth have their formations and dissolutions, cycles they cannot escape. As the *Book of Changes* says, "When heaven and earth perish, there is nothing by which to observe their transformations." The human body and the workings of creation share the same path, thus one may align with heaven and earth, assist in transformation and nurturance, regulate the Dao, and harmonize its principles. The former scholars did not speak of the unity of heaven and humanity’s governance as merely the oneness of heart and principle. That which governs is called the Emperor; its wondrous functioning is called ghosts and spirits—are they not one and the same? Thus, when the revolutions face adversity and decline, one must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel them.

When the stellar lodges deviate from their courses, their celestial positions errant and their shadow-measures awry; when the sun and moon lose their proper times, their waxings and wanings eclipsed—these, too, are confined by the numbers of delay, concealment, and retrogression. One must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel them. When the four seasons lose their order, cold and heat irregular; when yin and yang fall out of harmony, droughts and floods wreak havoc—these, too, arise from deviations in heaven and earth’s supreme harmony. One must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel them. When the sovereign faces calamity and warfare arises on all sides, all such disasters and conflicts stem from yin and yang’s rebellion and governance’s discord. Cultivating virtuous rule, reducing punishments, comforting the people, managing the military, appointing the worthy, and stabilizing the altars of soil and grain—these are the means to dissolve celestial portents and quell human suffering. This is the foremost duty of sagely rulers and worthy ministers. Yet if such calamities arise, one must also perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel and restrain them, thereby petitioning Heaven, which will surely quell disasters and send down auspiciousness.

When pestilential toxins spread and the multitudes perish, the *qi* of epidemic pestilence poisons the people, inevitably causing death and injury. One must perform purification rites and recite the scripture to dispel and release them, rectifying the *qi*’s conditions so that the pestilential *qi* subsides.

Those who attain the Dao do so through the scripture, thereby fully comprehending the most authentic and profound teachings, plumbing the depths of the most mysterious Dao. Inwardly seeking it, this is the way of the spirit dwelling in the Mud Pill Palace, the path of nurturing and refinement.

chunks.original_text: 正一嗣教道合无为阐祖光范真人领道教事四十三代天师张宇初注 诸天中大梵隐语无量音　道君撰 默庵曰：此即灵书中篇之序，引玉晨道君之所撰也。 诸天中者，即外四天之中也。 按《内旨经》云：元始天尊於赤明世界栢陵舍座，是时云雾郁勃，七日七夜，玄阴不解。 五老上白天尊曰：今日侍座，所未曾见。 天尊演教，则河海静默，山岳藏云。 今白日昼阴，天人惶惧，不审何故？ 天尊曰：今日诸天发瑞，灵应自然，玉字焕烂，障蔽天光。 咸令四座暝目。 俄顷天炁顿启，冥暗豁消，五色光明，洞照十方。 忽有灵书，字方一丈，现於空玄之上，文彩焕烂，八角垂芒，精光夺目，不可得睹。 天尊普告曰：此灵书八会，字无正形，其趣宛奥难可寻详。 可解注之。 於是，天真皇人受天尊明命，注解其旨，以付道君，使教诸天应得成真，有仙名者也。 观复曰：大梵者，元始大梵之炁，离合以成音梵之言。 隐语者，谓隐秘天中，世人不解。 无量音者，殊方异类，普闻妙义，初无限极，凡二百六十五字，分置三十二天，一天各八字。 又书於玄都官阙诸天楼观，则随人所习，乘炁各归其处矣。 以是大梵之音，遍闻无量而隐於诸天，非皇人按笔而不能传也。 或增入灵书上下篇，并龙篆正文，雷萧之所不取，故弗及之。 元始灵书中篇 默庵曰：灵书即大梵隐语无量之音玉字经也。 中篇即中央之篇也。 元始者，以其元始天尊所说，命天真皇人注释，以授道君。 灵书中篇，则大梵隐语中央之篇也。 观复曰：先真谓此灵书合於大易六十四卦，此经在天地之先，有卦象之前。 西王母云：九日导乾坤，母东覆两卦。 可见乾坤二卦始於此，继以屯蒙，终於既济、未济，为造化之纲维也。 次列六十甲子於下，明炁数终始循环也。 次系月建节侯十二卦者，以表一年阴阳代谢，寒署推迁也。 复别朔望盈虚，以明一月也。 又标十二时辰，以推一日火侯水符进退也。 盖以一年节侯，促於一月，以两日半准一月，复以十二卦以应十二时，又促一月归於一日也。 以一时准两日半，故上下卦象所用皆殊。 甲子节侯，其义亦别。 综而言之，上卦甲子经也，下卦节侯时晷纬也。 志心内观动静、消息、盈虚，自然得意志言，幽微之理尽在是矣。 则此篇之义，实与大易之妙，不期然而然。 元始说经，於羲皇未画之先，亦岂假易以明大梵之文也。 盖理一而已，是以若合符契，不待牵引附会而合矣。 以是考之，则自西王母而下，默庵少微诸师皆有象易之论，后皆以为始，於观复之见，其说亦浅矣。 今具总图於后，庶与邵子之《先天》，魏公之《参同》，彭公之《心镜》，皆默合焉。 其於阳火阴符进退之机，庶几乎尽矣。 东方八天 亶娄阿昔，无和　去声　观　音贯　音。 八字，黄曾天内音。 亶者，坦然广远之貌。 娄者，玉京山下长楼之名，上承玄都官。 阿者，玄都中阿那之神，掌楼之监，主大梵之炁。 炁数交周，则阿那鸣楼都之鼓以集众真，上朝元始。 苍者，帝君游台之名，以其苍蔚华秀也？ 无者，太元也。 言太无之中，自然能生真圣。 和者，日月门户之名。 言天中日月会於门。 观者，观觉也。 是天帝之讳。 音者，八字之音。 能诵之者，则真人乘金轮以开冥，玉女扬华旛以披剑，观觉主长夜之箓，四真技九幽之苦，七祖披朗，朽骸还生。

**Annotations by Zhang Yu Chu, the Forty-Third Celestial Master of the Orthodox Unity Lineage, Inheritor of the Dao, Expounder of Non-Action, Illustrious Ancestor, and Perfected Radiant Model, Overseer of Daoist Affairs**

**The Immeasurable Sounds of the Great Brahma Hidden Language in the Heavens**   *Composed by the Dao Lord*

Mò’ān observes: This is the preface to the central chapter of the *Numinous Writ*, transmitted from the Jade Dawn Dao Lord’s composition.

“The Heavens” refers to the midst of the Four Outer Heavens. According to the *Inner Pointer Scripture*: The Primordial Celestial Worthy, seated in the Cypress Mound Pavilion of the Crimson Clarity World, was enveloped in swirling mists for seven days and nights, the dark yin unyielding. The Five Elders addressed the Celestial Worthy, saying: “Today, as we attend your seat, we witness what has never been seen before.” When the Celestial Worthy expounded the teachings, rivers and seas fell silent, mountains and peaks concealed their clouds. Yet now, in broad daylight, the sky darkens, and heavenly beings tremble in fear—what is the cause? The Celestial Worthy replied: “Today, the Heavens emit auspicious signs, numinous responses arising naturally. Jade characters blaze with radiance, veiling the light of heaven. Let all present close their eyes.” In an instant, the celestial qi surged forth, the gloom dissolved, and five-colored light illumined the ten directions. Suddenly, a *Numinous Writ* appeared in the void above, each character a *zhang* in size, its resplendent script and eight-cornered rays dazzling the eye, impossible to behold directly. The Celestial Worthy proclaimed to all: “This *Numinous Writ* of the Eight Assemblies bears characters without fixed form, its purport profound and abstruse, difficult to fathom. Let it be annotated.” Thereupon, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign received the Celestial Worthy’s mandate to explicate its meaning and transmit it to the Dao Lord, that those in the Heavens destined for perfection—those with immortal names—might be instructed.

Guānfù observes: The *Great Brahma* refers to the qi of the Primordial Great Brahma, whose convergence and divergence produce the sounds of Brahma. *Hidden language* denotes the secrets concealed within the Heavens, incomprehensible to mortals. *Immeasurable sounds* signify that beings of all realms and kinds may hear its wondrous meaning without limit. Comprising two hundred and sixty-five characters, they are distributed across the Thirty-Two Heavens, eight characters to each. Inscribed upon the palaces and towers of the Mysterious Capital’s celestial bureaus, they align with each practitioner’s cultivation, allowing their qi to return to its proper abode. Thus, the sounds of the Great Brahma pervade the immeasurable yet remain hidden within the Heavens, untransmittable without the brush of the Perfected Sovereign. Some append the upper and lower chapters of the *Numinous Writ*, along with the Dragon Seal’s orthodox text—materials rejected by Lei Xiao—hence their omission here.

**The Central Chapter of the Primordial Numinous Writ**
Mò’ān observes: The *Numinous Writ* is the *Jade-Character Scripture of the Immeasurable Sounds of the Great Brahma Hidden Language*. The *central chapter* is the chapter of the Center. *Primordial* denotes that it was spoken by the Primordial Celestial Worthy, annotated by the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign, and transmitted to the Dao Lord. The *central chapter of the Numinous Writ* is thus the central chapter of the *Great Brahma Hidden Language*.

Guānfù observes: The Former Perfected declared that this *Numinous Writ* corresponds to the sixty-four hexagrams of the *Great Change*. This scripture predates Heaven and Earth, existing before the hexagrams. The Queen Mother of the West said: “Nine suns guide Qian and Kun; the Mother covers the two hexagrams in the East.” Thus, Qian and Kun originate here, followed by *Tun* and *Meng*, culminating in *Jiji* and *Weiji*, forming the warp and woof of creation. Below, the sixty *jiazi* cycles are arrayed, clarifying the qi’s numerical beginning and end. Next, the twelve hexagrams of the monthly nodes and seasonal markers illustrate the yearly alternation of yin and yang, the progression of cold and heat. Further distinctions of waxing and waning moons elucidate a single month. Twelve double-hours are then marked to regulate the daily advance and retreat of the fire-phase and water-tally. For the yearly seasonal markers are compressed into a month, two and a half days equating to one month, and the twelve hexagrams corresponding to the twelve double-hours, collapsing a month into a single day. Each double-hour equates to two and a half days, hence the upper and lower hexagrams differ in application. The *jiazi* cycles and seasonal markers thus serve distinct purposes. In sum, the upper hexagrams pertain to the *jiazi* scripture, while the lower hexagrams govern seasonal markers and temporal reckoning. By inwardly observing the mind’s movement and stillness, ebb and flow, one naturally grasps the intent and words, and the subtlest principles are fully contained herein. Thus, the meaning of this chapter aligns effortlessly with the wonders of the *Great Change*. The Primordial One expounded this scripture before Fu Xi drew the hexagrams—how could it rely on the *Change* to elucidate the Great Brahma’s text? The principle is one and the same; hence, they coincide like tallying tokens, requiring no forced alignment. By this reasoning, from the Queen Mother of the West onward, masters such as Mò’ān and Shǎowēi have all expounded on the *Change*’s imagery. Yet in Guānfù’s view, their interpretations remain superficial. Here, a comprehensive diagram is appended, harmonizing with Shào’s *Prior Heaven*, Wèi’s *Triplex Unity*, and Péng’s *Heart Mirror*. In its mechanism of advancing yang fire and retreating yin tally, it approaches perfection.

**The Eight Heavens of the East**
*Dǎnlóu āxī, wúhé guān yīn guàn yīn.*
Eight characters, the inner sounds of the Yellow-Canopy Heaven.
*Dǎn*: Vast and boundless in appearance.
*Lóu*: The name of the long tower beneath the Jade Capital Mountain, supporting the Mysterious Capital’s bureaus.
*Ā*: The Ānà spirit of the Mysterious Capital, overseer of the tower, steward of the Great Brahma’s qi. When the qi’s cycles complete, Ānà strikes the tower’s drum to assemble the Perfected, who ascend to pay homage to the Primordial One.
*Cāng*: The name of the Imperial Lord’s terrace, verdant and luxuriant.
*Wú*: The Great Vacuity. Within the Great Nothingness, true sages naturally arise.
*Hé*: The name of the gate of sun and moon. In the Heavens, sun and moon converge at this gate.
*Guān*: Perception. This is the Heavenly Emperor’s taboo name.
*Yīn*: The sound of the eight characters. Those who recite them will have Perfected Ones ride golden wheels to dispel darkness, Jade Maidens unfurl flowered banners and brandish swords, the Perceiver of Awakening preside over the ledgers of eternal night, the Four Perfected relieve the suffering of the Nine Dark Realms, the seven ancestors emerge into brightness, and withered bones revive.

chunks.original_text: 须延明首，法揽菩昙。 八字，玉完天内音。 须延者，玉完西北阙名。 大劫数交，须延於是而开，玉真上圣於是而回。 明首者，元始之都侯。 元始开运，则都候启道，梵行诸炁，倏忽自朗。 法者，法轮罪福之场； 揽者，觉也。 天帝君之讳，主度魂更生。 菩者，菩提也，执九色之节。 昙者，昙颐也，把十绝之旛。 并上元真人，能常诵洞章，则法轮引籍，揽觉度魂，菩提转轮，昙赜扬旛，天地得之以不倾，万物得之以长存也。 青元曰：法揽菩昙，即玉清四府真人也。 稼那阿奕，忽诃流吟。 八字，何童天内音。 稼那者，天中主图之号，领人间生死图录，总主神仙，治金华之宫。 阿奕乃七宝林中树名，弥覆四方，实上圣游圃真人戏园也。 忽者，觉也，飞天神人名。 主大小劫会。 诃者，诃摩也，天中呼元始天尊为诃摩。 流吟者，流布歌吟也。 劫运既终，诃摩开化教法，普度天人，将来劫坏，真经隐藏，天尊已知，预为歌音也。 人能常诵洞章，则主图先生削罪录於长夜，注生名於南宫。 华都曲丽，鲜菩育臻。 八字，平育天内音。 华都者，天中太极宫青华门之别名。 曲者，天中梵天神人飞行太极之上，爽灵风之炁，歌洞章之曲。 丽者，太和玉女名也。 鲜者，鲜云，即庆云也。 菩者，天中楼名。 育者，天中帝君隐名。 臻者，至也。 育帝常乘八景之轮，游观八极之外，回十绝之灵旛以召天魔举度天人，常能诵此洞章，则飞天遥唱，三界司迎，七祖出离长夜，上升南宫。 答落大梵，散烟庆云。 八字，文举天内音。 答者，天中玉阙之名。 落者，宫阙落落然也。 大者，大宥天尊开化运之初，皆放大赦，谓之大宥。 使三恶道空，九幽罢对。 梵者，梵行之炁，开龙汉之劫，运赤明之辰也。 散烟者，真人散香烟於玉关。 庆云者，五色之祥云也。 庆云接乎紫馆，飞天舞乎空轮。 青元曰：元始时开大赦，答落官庭，放释罪魂。 飞洒玉都，明魔上门。 八字，摩夷天内音。 飞者，飞天神王之号。 天地改运，沦於延康，冥冥无开，飞天启光散晖，诸天受炁洒者，龙汉一会，倏忽而回。 玉者，玉真，主开长夜之圣号。 都者，九幽酆都。 人有善功，则玉真开长夜之户酆都度八难之场。 七祖返生，幽魂还光也。 明者，解八字之义。 魔者魔王也。 上者，上帝也。 门者，直门下之人，能明识八字之义； 则魔王敬伏，上帝养育於始生之门。 门下有韩君司命司录，度算於南宫，庆流九族，生死蒙恩。 无行上首，回跖流玄。 八字，越衡天内音。 无者，上道也。 言元始之炁开明无上之道。 行者，天元之纲纪，维罗八极，梵炁弥布，流行不息也。 上首者，北斗之录罪宫也。 转运天关，推会度数，数极则大劫交也。 回者，转也。 跖者，履也。 劫运之初，元始则履空而轮转，布化於十方。 流者，流三晨之光，照长夜之府。 玄者，空也。 越衡天上玄都之景，有空峰之山，乃万圣之所游，生死之所归。 道未足备身应灭度，魂升空峰，受炼而升南宫也。 阿陁龙罗，四象吁员。 八字，蒙翳天内音。 阿者，天中有九折之山，连阿相属。 陁者，山上之楼，上通玉清之熙，以望三界之乡，帝君尝游阿丘之岭，下监万生之罪。 龙者，龙山与阿陁相去九亿万里。 罗者，日月之名。
